story: On August 30, 2014 Kevin Marshall Founder of F.I.D. ENT “Father's 'Involved Daily” will be holding his 1st event at the Hipps Folly Pavilion 8th & Alabama in Ft. Dix NJ, 08640 from 1pm-8pm. This event is a celebration for all the good fathers throughout the tri-state area because so many good fathers in the world are not appreciated and overlooked.  This day is a day of recognition of those men and the impact they make in their own families and in this society.  Fathers and families are invited to join us for a day of excitement, entertainment and for the children fun games.  In addition there will be music, sporting events, water play, moon bounce, clowns, food, vendors, giveaways, networking, and most important of all a memorable day with your family.  There is no cost for admission but we ask that you register before attending.  We look forward to seeing you there!

story:
A Brief Introduction

I am a 29-year-old man, dedicated to living creatively, generously and with integrity. I am a husband, son, brother, spoken word poet, arts organizer, Quaker, epicurean and educator.

 

The Vision

My dream is to combine the creative, expressive and healing arts in exciting new ways:

  • by working with young men to develop positive self-identity,
  • by helping groups and communities to develop simple therapeutic skills to support one another,
  • and by continuing to expand our ideas about what is possible in the realm of mental health and wellness.

 

The Donations

This summer I was accepted into the graduate program at the Kutenai Art Therapy Institute. Now it’s time to fund it.

Up until now, my wife, Kate, and I have been living on under $15,000 a year. We live simply and tend to favor having time to do things ourselves rather than having money to pay to have things done. Though I have applied for several scholarships, there are a limited number of them for Master’s programs in Art Therapy. In the end, I have taken out loans to pay for the program: $10,500 for the first year and $8590 for the second, not including the cost of books or living expenses.

The money raised by this IndieGoGo campaign will directly offset this tuition, decreasing the amount we need to borrow.

 

The Perks

In thanks, I’ve prepared a banquet of perks for you to choose from: one package for each funding tier.  Many of these include variations on my poetry. If you haven't heard it before, check out the link to my CD below or watch a video of my work.

Select the package you’d like most and don’t be afraid to treat yourself!

  • Thank You Card w/ Personal Recipe – Receive a Thank You card, either in person or by mail, designed by me. Find enclosed a recipe for one of my favourite dishes, sauces or treats!
  • Poetry Poster – One of my original poems made into a beautifully designed poster to be hung on your wall.
  • Cloak of a Culture CD – A signed copy of my spoken word CD, released in 2009, with 10 tracks of performance poetry. You can preview it here at http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/radiantraven
  • Brand New Chapbook – This collection of my poetry is so brand new it hasn’t been titled yet! A handmade book of my poetry, writings and illustrations.
  • Video Performance and Written Copy of Personalized Poem – You and I collaborate on a theme for a poem I write, record and transcribe. Just for you. Some perks include a poetry poster of the personalized poem (see Poetry Poster perk above)
  • Hand-knit 100% Wool Scarf and Toque (knit by my wife Kate) – What can I say? She’s a brilliant knitter with an eye for style and she’ll customize it just for you.
  • Art therapy sessions for someone in need – After graduation I will offer these sessions to a low-income person, family or group, free of charge and sponsored by you.
  • Dinner and a Show – Wouldn’t this be fun?

 

Why Not Just Stick With Loans?

It’s true that taking out student loans has become a common way to pay for higher education. Chances are that if you have a degree, you probably borrowed money to get it.

It’s also true that many debt-carrying graduates are forced into choosing employment based on wages or salary rather than on where their gifts, passions and strengths lie. And it’s true that while higher education is paid for by the state in many European countries, the cost of the same education in Canada is increasing at an accelerating rate each year.

I believe that many people would prefer to support a young person’s vision of supporting his community’s well-being than to see that same student shackled by debt—especially when that vision is one of service.

 

Other Ways to Help

Even the smallest donation is a help, but there are other ways to support this vision. Take a moment to tell someone you think might be interested about this campaign. IndieGoGo provides some simple “share tools” to make this easy. Or, better yet, mention it in person!

story:
Even though our campaign was not 100% a success we are still continuing to use other methods of fundraising and we promise all of you that your donation will still contribute towards helping us get a 3D printer for our school. Thank You!
Who we are:
The Balboa RepRap is a 3D printing and Industrial design club. What exactly is that? A club where we learn about product design and how consumer products are developed from an idea into a product on the shelf. We will learn about 3D modeling software (CAD) and how to use it to turn our ideas into a model that can be manipulated to show the envisioned productï¿½s look. An important part of the industrial design process is prototyping, this determines what works and what doesnï¿½t work about a product. Our club wants to use 3D printers as a way to prototype our products. We hope to learn more about hobby 3D printing and the role it may take in the future as the primary form of production.

What we plan to do:
Our club is currently trying to develop an industrial design curriculum with RepRap (hobby 3D printing) incorporated. Our curriculum must be easy to understand, engaging and hands-on. Our club is currently not a class and each member who is in the club is there to learn about Industrial Design and 3D printing. The point of our club is not to be a strict classroom environment. We hope to make it into a community where ideas can be pitched and incorporated with othersï¿½ ideas. We want to give a hands-on approach to learning. We plan to have 3D modeling lessons to learn how to use software such as 123D and sketchup. In addition, our club wants to bring 3D printing to the hands of teens. This will give them the opportunity to see the technology in action and experience first hand the infinite possibilities that this technology can create.

Why we are needed:
With industrial arts classes like woodshop and metal shop cut from our schools in San Francisco, our school no longer supports the needs of hands-on activities is a facilitated environment. Our club will fill this need, by teaching how to use a 3D printer and design models to print. This will open up the doors for creativity and hopefully inspire students to use this technology to create practical things. By supporting this club you are giving youth the opportunity for them to create something awesome that may inspire students in the careers of engineering. Our club will change the way we view the world!

What we need:
Our club currently wants to purchase a 3D printer. Though our video says that we want to purchase a Makerbot, we may purchase a 3D printer like the Printrbot or huxley due to price. The goal is $2000 which will allow us to purchase both the materials for the printer and other costs like possibly drawing tablets. With your support I really believe that we can make this project a success! Happy Holidays!

story:
Our Story

CIACAC was formed when Neuza Nacimiento, a mother of a pre-adolecent boy, became discouraged with the social opportunities available for young people living in the Jardim Berdim Mar favela where they live.  At the time, the neighborhood was experiencing a particularly insecure and violent period due to clashes between rival narco-trafficking groups. Baile Funk parties were the only place where local youth could meet, and Neuza worried this environment was not a healthy one for young people.  She wanted them to have the opportunity to see the world outside of the favela.  


In 2001, Neuza put together a group of 8 local children.  The purpose of this group was to go on excursions to universities, theatres, beaches: anywhere where the children could get out of the favela and experience some of the treasures of Rio de Janeiro (many of which were unknown and inaccessible to the children, despite having lived there their whole lives).  Neuza, who is a writer, says, "I became a writer because I saw someoe writing and that showed me that it is possible.  I thought that smelling the air of the university would help generate an ambition in the children for something different than what they could see in the favela." The group was called "A Look into Other Things", and it was the seed of what has today become CIACAC.


CIACAC is now registered in Brazil as a non-governmental organization.  It recieves a constant flow of local and foreign volunteers, and offers an ongoing program of classes for children and adolescents ranging in topic from Guitar to English to Capoeira.  Despite this measurable growth and success, CIACAC is still a very small, very grass-roots organization essentially run by Neuza alone in her own house. She first funded the organization with the money she earned working in houses in the wealthy South Zone of the city (Neuza started in this line of work when she was 8 years old). Ever since her money ran out, CIACAC has been funded by sporadic donations from volunteers. This money is not reliable, and Neuza has been looking for ways to make CIACAC self-sustainable.


In 2011, a group of 8 volunteers from Spain came to do a month-long project with CIACAC.  They stayed in a room at Neuza's neighbor's house, and recieved breakfast and lunch.  Neuza thought, "Why not build an addition to my own house where volunteers can stay? They can pay a small amount for room and board and this will generate some income, enough to keep CIACAC going." With a few generous donations and international fund-raising efforts, Neuza was able to begin the addition.  She has added a new level to her house where 8 volunteers will be able to sleep, cook, and bathe. As I write this, the construction nears completion.  But much work remains: cementing the block walls, finishing the floors, painting everything, instaling electricity, and all of the unpredictable variables that come up with such a project. CIACAC has run out of money.  Neuza estimates that the project needs another $6,000 to reach completion, at which point she can open the doors of her already very open house.


The Impact

CIACAC has run for the last 10 years on anything is could get. Volunteers come and go (but many who spend time here remain committed after they have left Rio); money comes from bursts of generocity on the part of individuals; used clothes show up sometimes from a youth hostel in Copacabana.  CIACAC has recieved furniture from a generous company called Lorinvest, and computers from a Spanish organization called IPC Pandora. It's incredible how much has been accomplished and how many people around the world have connected to this project. Still, CIACAC lacks any kind of security.  The only constants are Neuza and the children.


Building the hostel addition to her house will free Neuza from a bit of this insecurity.  It will allow CIACAC's international volunteer program to generate an income that will sustain the project as a whole.  In the meantime, volunteers will be better organized and closer to the community in which they work.  The volunteer hostel is a solution that makes good use of what already exists.


What We Need & What You Get


CIACAC is looking for $6,000.  This sum is an estimate, and we hope it will cover the expenses that remain on finishing the extension. This job has already been started and is, in fact, very near to completion.  What remains to be done?  Well, we need to pay the workers.  We need to finish the celings, and the floors of the bedroom and kitchen.  The windows and doors need to be intalled, as does electricity. On the roof, we have to erect a wall so that volunteers can hang out up there and enjoy the breeze (and maybe grill a little Brazilian churrasco!). It would be nice to be able to paint the walls, too (I've already volunteered to do this work, we just need the paint). And then, there are the random things that come up.  An extra bag of cement here, a PVC pipe there.  

We will raise this money because we have to. But if we could raise it now, with IndieGoGo, CIACAC could start hosting volunteers that much sooner.  The sooner CIACAC can start accommodating the volunteers who are already inquiring about arrival dates in March, April, May...the sooner CIACAC can start taking advantage of having a degree of stability.


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell others about CIACAC!

Other Ways You Can Help

campaign_city: Parada de Lucas, Rio de Janeiro, Brazil

story:
What is BiSHoP?

My name is Caroline Calderon. I am the Outreach Coordinator for the Bill Sorro Housing Program (BiSHoP), which is a program of the Veterans Equity Center, a non-profit initially established to serve Filipino World War II Veterans, many of whom reside in the South of Market (SoMa). BiSHoP was formed to address the housing needs of the SoMa community. We currently serve a vast target population that includes adults living with disabilties, formerly incarcerated individuals, families, seniors, immigrants, members of the LGBT community, veterans, and South of Market residents and workers.

What's the cause?

BiSHoP is currently in the process of building our internship program. We will be training students, community advocates, and individuals from all walks of life on housing issues that the South of Market community faces. Interns will be assisting SOMA residents and workers in applying for affordable housing opportunities in San Francisco. I hope that through this internship, interns will work alongside community members and help address and outline the needs of the community.

 

How will your donation benefit the cause?

Our internship is just starting! So we definitely need the funds to kickstart it off right. Your monies will help put food on the table during our meetings, pay for intern supplies and necessities (office supplies, travel expenses, etc.), fund future community outreach events that will be organized by our interns, and most importantly, your donation will help build the foundation and resources that our internship needs to make an impact in the community.

Additional Questions?

Should you have additional questions, please contact me directly at bishop@vetsequitycenter.org. If you're uncomfortable donating online, you are more than welcome to donate cash/check in person.

story:
My Story

Hi there,

I'm Bram van Leuken and I'm 24 years old. I'm a Dutch student at the Academy for Popculture of the Hanze institute in Leeuwarden, Netherlands. This page will contain my mandatory internship for my bachelor degree. 


After months of negotiating, my internship at Duck Down Music is secured. My internship will take place from november 1st 2011 till march 31th 2012 in Manhattan, New York City! 


The Impact

For a Dutch student, this kind of internship is exceptional and a beautiful opportunity to gain knowledge and experience in the city where everything can happen. 

This is an once in a lifetime opportunity to experience the way of life in New York and to have inside intelligence in the music branche. The knowledge, experience and wisdom I gain are very valuable. Inside intelligence in the music branche of the United States and, especially New York, are so helpful to build a strong surface for myself to share that knowledge and wisdom in the Netherlands. I want to stimulate the music branche in the Netherlands and Europe to create new opportunities and concepts to fill the gap. It's not only for me, it's for a greater good!


Motivation and devotion are the keywords to describe my characteristics to succeed in everything I do and love. For me, this opportunity to intern at such a prominent organisation in the music branche in the United States is truly a blessing.


What We Need & What You Get

No organisation nor foundation in the Netherlands will/can support me financial so I have to apply for a loan, since I haven't got the required amount of money.


I've worked long days the last couple of months, but an internship for five months in New York requires a lot of money including: flightticket, visa application, housing, public transport, insurance and necessities.  

The overall prices for groceries in New York are more expensive than the prices in the Netherlands. 


Here is a financial overview for my internship for five months:


- $900,-      Flight-ticket 

- $1.525,-    Visa application + Basic medical insurance

- $3.500,-    Housing

- $3.375,-    Primary necessities

- $375,-      Public transport

- $85,-        Travel insurance

- $80,-        Supplementary insurance

- $200,-     Third Party Insurance


[EDIT! Had a stroke of luck!!]

I've earned around $7.500 My overall (primary) expenses are calculated around $10,000. This means I have to gather around $2,500 to realize my internship without a loan. 


My entire goal is to cover all the expenses, of course. But as you may understand, every cent is a blessing. If I don't reach my entire goal, every dollar I've gained has a positive effect on the budget.


I will keep you up to date with a blog regarding my internship, experiences, adventures and crazyness during my stay in New York. If you support me, I'll give you a shoutout in my blog or post links to your music, if you're a musician. It's all about spreading the word out for the benefit of all! If you live in the New York area, I'll give you a beer, if my budget allows it ;-)


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word on facebook, twitter or other social media to support this once in a lifetime time opportunity. 


Many thanks in advance if you support me to make it all happen! Any publicity and gestures will be highly appreciated!

This is an once in a lifetime opportunity to experience the way of life in New York and to have inside intelligence in the music branche. The knowledge, experience and wisdom I gain are very valuable. Inside intelligence in the music branche of the United States and, especially New York, are so helpful to build a strong surface for myself to share that knowledge and wisdom in the Netherlands. I want to stimulate the music branche in the Netherlands and Europe to create new opportunities and concepts to fill the gap. It's not only for me, it's for a greater good!

Motivation and devotion are the keywords to describe my characteristics to succeed in everything I do and love. For me, this opportunity to intern at such a prominent organisation in the music branche in the United States is truly a blessing.


What We Need & What You Get
No organisation nor foundation in the Netherlands will/can support me financial so I have to apply for a loan, since I haven't got the required amount of money.

I've worked long days the last couple of months, but an internship for five months in New York requires a lot of money including: flightticket, visa application, housing, public transport, insurance and necessities.  
The overall prices for groceries in New York are more expensive than the prices in the Netherlands. 

Here is a financial overview for my internship for five months:

- $900,-      Flight-ticket 
- $1.525,-    Visa application + Basic medical insurance
- $3.500,-    Housing
- $3.375,-    Primary necessities
- $375,-      Public transport
- $85,-        Travel insurance
- $80,-        Supplementary insurance
- $200,-     Third Party Insurance

[EDIT! Had a stroke of luck!!]
I've earned around $7.500 My overall (primary) expenses are calculated around $10,000. This means I have to gather around $2,500 to realize my internship without a loan. 

My entire goal is to cover all the expenses, of course. But as you may understand, every cent is a blessing. If I don't reach my entire goal, every dollar I've gained has a positive effect on the budget.

I will keep you up to date with a blog regarding my internship, experiences, adventures and crazyness during my stay in New York. If you support me, I'll give you a shoutout in my blog or post links to your music, if you're a musician. It's all about spreading the word out for the benefit of all! If you live in the New York area, I'll give you a beer, if my budget allows it ;-)

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word on facebook, twitter or other social media to support this once in a lifetime time opportunity. 

Many thanks in advance if you support me to make it all happen! Any publicity and gestures will be highly appreciated!

story:
The Opportunity for Healing and Transformation 

As a graduate student of Drama Therapy and Mental Health Counseling in Seattle, Washington, I see theatre and the expressive arts as powerful tools in healing individuals suffering from grief and trauma, empowering people to transform their lives, and in inspiring people to create a socially just and environmentally sustainable world.

 

In June 2011, I have the opportunity to join drama therapists and fellow students in urban and village settings in Kenya and Uganda, where we will exchange knowledge and techniques with African theatre practitioners, counselors, social workers, and other group leaders who help heal and transform their communities.

 

Using applied theatre and drama therapy methods, our work with community leaders will focus on several outcomes:

 

  • In Nairobi, Kenya, working with the Amani People's Theatre (www.aptkenya.org), we will focus on street children in remand homes

 

  • In Budondo village, Uganda, working with the Atua Theatre Troupe, we will focus on women’s reproductive health

 

  • In the Great Rift Valley in northern Kenya, and villages near the coast of the Indian Ocean, we will focus on  preventing election-related violence

 

  • In Northern Uganda, we will focus on rehabilitating and healing trauma in child soldiers after 20 years of war.


Prior to going to Kenya and Uganda, I will receive intensive training from the leadership for this service adventure. Debriefing and reflection sessions after each phase of the work will utilize theatre, movement and somatic practices.

 

The mission of those who I will be joining is to find the bridges between personal exploration and service to humanity. The leaders will use their expertise in Theatre of the Oppressed, Developmental Transformations, Playback Theatre, Psychodrama/ Sociodrama, Contact Improvisation and Authentic Movement.

Since 2007 they have been collaborating with African theatre practitioners in a cultural exchange. Together

we will be cultivating an approach that combines African and American perspectives on personal and societal healing through the theatre arts.

 

Who I Will Be Working With

I will undertake this service with drama therapists with significant experience in Kenya and Uganda, as well as significant experience in Theatre of the Oppressed, Playback Theatre, Applied Theatre and Developmental Transformations. Leading the trip will be the following:

  • Mecca Burns, MA, RDT-BCT,  a founding member of Presence, is a Registered Drama Therapist and Board-Certified Trainer. She has served as Project Director for the Charlottesville Living History Initiative for the past four years.  She contributed two chapters to the textbook: Interactive and Improvisational Drama: Varieties of Applied Theatre and Performance [Adam Blatner, 2007]. Her chapters are called “Theatre of the Oppressed” and “Cultivating a Presence in a Community Through Applied Theatre”.  She was a research associate for Transforming Leadership: A New Pursuit of Happiness [James MacGregor Burns, 2005]. Mecca has previously worked with Amani People's Theatre and Atua Theatre Troupe. www.contactpresence.org

  • Brad Stoller, MFA is an award winning playwright and performer.  Brad is accomplished in various forms of  movement practices which he has studied over the past 25 years including Contact Improvisation, Aikido, Yoga, and the Alexander Technique.  He is a member of two improvisational theatre companies and is presently the president of the McGuffey Artists Association in Charlottesville, VA.  He is the Set and Lighting designer for Hampton Sydney College and also teaches playwriting and theatre history. Brad also has previously worked with Amani People's Theatre and Atua Theatre Troupe. www.contactpresence.org

  • Fred Landers, MA, RDT-BCT, CAT, is a Registered Drama Therapist and Board Certified Trainer, with significant training in Developmental transformations (DvT). He practices drama therapy in New York City, working with post-traumatic stress disorder, violence and sexually abused children. Fred has taught drama therapy in China, Vietnam and other countries. www.codaptiveplay.com


  • Armani People's Theatre www.aptkenya.org
 
  • Atua Theatre Troupe and Budondo Intercultural Centre http://budondo.wordpress.com/

My Background

I am a graduate student at Antioch University in Seattle, Washington, working on a Master's of Arts degree in Psychology with specialization in Drama Therapy and Mental Health Counseling. I am particularly interested in working with grief and trauma, and with transforming hearts through sacred story and the expressive arts.

 

I currently work as a Program Specialist at Fairfax Hospital in Kirkland, Washington, an acute inpatient psychiatric facility providing treatment to adults, adolescents and children. I am hoping that my work in Kenya and Uganda will build upon my drama therapy and compassionate listening skills, and will be useful in my day to day work at Fairfax Hospital.

 

I also work as a Research Assistant for Landesa, a nonprofit that works to secure land rights for the poorest of the poor around the world, particularly women and girls. Since Landesa works with women and girls in Kenya and Uganda, I am hoping that my work on this service trip will provide me insight into the people that we serve at Landesa.

 

Other ways that that this fits into my life experience and passions:

 

  • I was trained as a Doula, so working with women on reproductive health issues will be meaningful and rich.
  • I have practiced environmental law for over 20 years and am a facilitator of the Pachamama Alliance's Awakening the Dreamer Symposiums. Working with the village of Budondo on achieving their dreams for environmental sustainability will be one of my goals. 
  • I will receive amazing training and experience from several experienced drama therapists and hope to earn credit towards my Master's degree and/or my prerequisites for becoming a Registered drama therapist.
  • Do you really need any more reasons to support me? This is a win win all around!
    • You can learn more about me at my personal website, Spirit Heart Journeys, www.spiritheartjourneys.com

    What I Need & What You Get

    In order to seize this opportunity, I will need to raise money to cover the cost of travel and expenses while I am away (approximately $2,000 for airfare, $20/day for living expenses, plus local travel expenses, visas, etc. ). Any assistance you can provide me will help make this dream a reality.

     

    You can also help me by getting the word out to others through facebook, email, twitter and conversation. Talk it up with your friends, family and coworkers!

story:
As cuts to education budgets continue to mount, universities have cut professional development & travel funds. Fewer student affairs and higher education professionals have the opportunity to learn from others, share knowledge, and develop as professionals.

BreakDrink is in the process of changing formats to help fill the professional development void. BreakDrink has already hosted 1 online Student Affairs Conference, and has set a goal to host 3 conferences annually, with a capacity of 1,000 live participants each session. All educational sessions will be recorded and archived online for anyone to view and share, any time. Additionally, we are planning to launch 10 podcasts over the next year, kicking it off with 3 this summer, focusing on niche areas of higher education such as Greek Life, Residence Life, and Education Technology.

Funds raised will help launch the podcast by supplying the host with microphones, compensate fees for podcast software, and for the purchase of a computer to create a media center and sound studio. We will be transparent when posting the amount raised, and how the money is spent, via the website.

You can find more information at http://breakdrink.com/funding
Thank you for your support. Please send any questions to Jeff at breakdrink@gmail.com

story:
Hello friends of Greenhornets baseball!

It's hard to believe spring is almost here!  You know what that means? BASEBALL! 

For boys in the 3rd and 4th grade, generally 9 years old and under, the Greenhornets program offers an opportunity to play baseball at a level higher than traditional 'club' baseball.  This is referred to as 9U Travel baseball.  This is a team comprised of 12 boys who were selected by the coaching staff following two days of intense tryouts involving 30 plus boys in the fall of 2012.   These boys should be congratulated for their hard work and achievement. 

Severna Park baseball, like most sports in the area, is played almost year round when you consider spring baseball, fall ball and winter workouts.  The Boys 9U travel team started playing together in the fall of 2012.  This winter they worked on baseball skills indoors.  Now they are ready to move outside for some real baseball practice before the season begins in March 2013. 

It's a long season requiring a huge commitment of time and money from everyone involved.  100% of your donation, less a minimal fee charged by Indiegogo, will go towards costs of equipment, uniforms, league fees, tournament fees, umpire fees, travel costs, etc.

Typical costs range from $400 to $600 per boy for the season.  Our goal is to raise $2,000 or close to it by the mid April 2013.  We thank you for your consideration.  Please share this website with friends and family you feel may want to contribute.  You can do this by sending them a link to this website or using the Indiegogo Share Tools.  Don't forget to check out the nice perks we are offering for your generous donation!


Player who generates the most donation money will receive a $75 Dick's Sporting Goods gift card!


thanks,

Boys 9U Travel Team Coaching Staff

story:
Short Summary

Differences Magazine is a positive online only teen magazine catering to teens and young adults 14-22 yrs old. We provide a platform of resources and as well provide our audience with a way to discuss issues they face day to day.  

We are hosting our first ever Making A Difference Empowerment Conference for girls.  We believe this is a great opportunity for us to make a difference in girls lives as well as provide them with tools to empower them as they go through life.

By contributing to this campaign you will help us not only make a difference, but educate, motivate and provide these girls with a sense of accomplishment along with the necessary tools for them to move forward with whatever they choose to do. 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $2,500 in order to make this conference successful.  We will use these funds to secure speakers, provide raffle prizes, workshops, and goodie bags for the girls, last but not least it will help provide them with lunch during the conference. 

See perks to the right*

The Impact

We believe this conference is valuable and necessary to the girls that will be in attendance.   This will provide girls with an opportunity to be exposed to certain topics, speakers and activities that they otherwise would be unable to have due to distance, finances, etc. 

This conference will cover the following topics: S.T.E.M., Nutrition/Body Image,  Volunteering, Bullying, Financial literacy, Social Media, and Global Awareness. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some of you may not be able to contribute financially, however you can still help.  You can help us by spreading the word in regards to Differences Magazine and what we are doing!  You can also send individuals that you feel align with our objective our way.

story:
THE OPPORTUNITY: Every year tens of thousands of well meaning college students travel to impoverished communities to volunteer their labor to help the communities get out of poverty.
 
THE PROBLEM: Most of these volun-tourists don't have the skills to effectively help, and often make things worse, like someone who has not been trained in CPR trying to guess where to push on someone's rib cage. 
 
THE SOLUTION: Cory has spent years developing the trainings that these volun-tourists need, and is now ready to bring them to life in a web based training program called University Without Borders. Both universities and NGO's on the ground have endorsed the training content, and are looking forward to it coming to life!
 
ACTION: Watch the Video above, open your heart, and make a contribution to support the creation of the first training video product, Human-Centered Development 101.
 

Special Edition T's Designed for Our Generour Contributors of $100+

 

Thank you for your support to help KickStart our Education Program.  All of our supporters will become "Part of the Action."  We will update you as the program and the company develops and supports people all over the world to enagage in the fight againts poverty. 

NOTE: EndingPovertyTogether.Org is a Social Business that is dedicated to Supporting Poverty Alleviation Work Worldwide through a Profitable Business Model 

Learn More:

CLICK HERE to watch Video Interview about the PRODUCT and CORY's Story

Serving impoverished communities in need is kinda like CPR:  You can save someone's life but you had better be trained first or else you can cause more problems then you're helping.  The Launch of "Human-Centered Development 101" will give interested and passionate global activists the foundational information and perspectives to engage as an empowered international volunteer.  Lets leave behind the days in which we assume that "something is better than nothing" and that "good intentions are all that really matters."  

Please support the launch of this Video Education Product and We promise to use the funds effectively and responsibly. (For More Information about "Human-Centered Development.") If you have any questions at all please do not hesitate to email coryglazier@gmail.com and we'll post the answers to the FAQ.

Testimonials

People Who have gone through the live workshop version of "Human-Centered Development 101” :

"This information will change the way we deliver International Aid. It will put our money to better use and deepen our connection to the communities we work with. I can't wait to share this valuable information with my peers."  - Student  

"Cory's enthusiasm and passion was truly inspiring. Learning about how to help others build community and initiate empowerment to help end poverty was powerful. This was an eye-opening training everyone should take!"  - RN

"Cory's enthusiasm, dedication, experience, and profound wisdom on international aid make him a truly inspiring mentor; his perspective has been instrumental in redirecting the focus of our project towards sustainability."  - Engineer

CLICK HERE to See Video Testimonials 

 

Use of Funds:

> Salaries of people working full-time on the project, including Cory

> Branding and Marketing

 > Travel/ Speaking/ Networking

 > Legal Costs

 > Website Development

> Video Work/ Product Development

 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES

The work that we have ahead of us is pretty straight forward. We are extremely fortunate to have a strong Advisory team who have respectfully been through all these steps before. We will be using professional contractors to help with the graphic design, video editing, animation, marketing materials and product launch strategy. Unlike many projects, this one does not have too many variables. We have already proven market interest and content value. If you have any other questions please feel free to contact us directly: info@endingpovertytogether.org

story:
The Churchville-Chili community was stunned this week when we learned of the sudden and tragic loss of a man that shaped nearly every student he encountered in his 20+ years of teaching at Churchville-Chili High School.  Rob Coats, "Mr. Coats",  connected with all students, regardless of their backgrounds and beliefs.  One student recalled that 20 years ago, Mr. Coats was able to quell "teen angst " and showed students that "there was a place in the world for odd balls and weirdos."  Ultimately, Rob made a lasting impact on everyone he met.  As his Facebook is flooded with messages of disbelief, the class of 1994 (one of Rob's first) and others have called for a Memorial Fund to devote to causes that embody Rob's commitment to education and acceptance.  We plan on looking at options to set up a Robert P. Coats Scholarship fund and talk to his wife and family about which charities best represent his personal mission.  I am starting with a goal of $47,000 which represents $1,000 for each year Mr. Coats was on this earth.  All money that is received will be donated to a scholarship in Rob's name, causes that his family believes represent his ideals, and/or his family.  Rest in Peace Mr. Coats.  Though you are gone, you and your legacy of encouraging independent thought and expression will not be forgotten.

 

Rob's facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/mobileprotection#!/rob.coats

 

Rob's blog: http://granolabox.tumblr.com/
story_txt:
The Churchville-Chili community was stunned this week when we learned of the sudden and tragic loss of a man that shaped nearly every student he encountered in his 20+ years of teaching at Churchville-Chili High School.  Rob Coats, "Mr. Coats",  connected with all students, regardless of their backgrounds and beliefs.  One student recalled that 20 years ago, Mr. Coats was able to quell "teen angst " and showed students that "there was a place in the world for odd balls and weirdos."  Ultimately, Rob made a lasting impact on everyone he met.  As his Facebook is flooded with messages of disbelief, the class of 1994 (one of Rob's first) and others have called for a Memorial Fund to devote to causes that embody Rob's commitment to education and acceptance.  We plan on looking at options to set up a Robert P. Coats Scholarship fund and talk to his wife and family about which charities best represent his personal mission.  I am starting with a goal of $47,000 which represents $1,000 for each year Mr. Coats was on this earth.  All money that is received will be donated to a scholarship in Rob's name, causes that his family believes represent his ideals, and/or his family.  Rest in Peace Mr. Coats.  Though you are gone, you and your legacy of encouraging independent thought and expression will not be forgotten.
 
Rob's facebook page: http://www.facebook.com/mobileprotection#!/rob.coats
 
Rob's blog: http://granolabox.tumblr.com/

story: Each year the Iota Pi Omega gives thousands of dollars in scholarship funding to deserving students in Brevard County, Florida.  Your donation to this cause will not only help Kayla, but other deserving young people will also be assisted with college education expenses.  You are also welcomed to join us as we celebrate Kayla's accomplishments along with 9 other young ladies on Saturday, October 27th, 6 pm at the Rialto Hilton in Cocoa Beach.  Tickets are $45.00

story:
Our Story


Since opening its doors in spring of 2010, the Afghanistan National Institute of Music (ANIM) has been working to rebuild the social and cultural life of Afghanistan by providing a safe, tuition-free, and musically rich learning environment for the children of Kabul and its surrounding villages.


I traveled to Kabul last winter as a guest artist of ANIM’s Winter Academy. I led a small delegation of musicians from Boston’s New England Conservatory, where I am Assistant Chair of the Department of Contemporary Improvisation. Eden MacAdam-Somer, Larry Unger and I were struck by the vitality, enthusiasm, accomplishment and musical appetite of ANIM’s students. We were struck, too, by the dedication of ANIM’s Afghan and international faculty who work tirelessly towards their students’ future.


I will be returning to Kabul from August 1 - 15 to offer private lessons, and to help prepare advanced students to step into teaching roles.


The Impact

Music has been subject to extreme censorship in Afghanistan. Under the Taliban rule, singing and dancing were prohibited, musical instruments were confiscated and destroyed, and professional musicians were forced into silence or exile. The consequences of musical censorship for the Afghan people, culture and heritage have been profound and far-reaching. Much progress has been made since the Taliban were deposed in 2001, but Afghanistan faces many challenges as it rebuilds a shattered political, economic and social infrastructure.


Under the direction of founder Dr. Ahmad Sarmast, the Afghanistan National Institute off Music provides a safe, tuition-free learning environment for students regardless of gender, ethnicity or social class. Half of the school’s students are drawn from Afghanistan’s population of orphans and child laborers: these students receive both academic and musical training. The families of child labourers receive a monthly stipend roughly equal to the child’s monthly earnings. Just $30 keeps a child in school instead of working the streets.


Guest artists can play a vital role in ANIM's mission. Here are a few ways my residency will make a valuable contribution:


  • As in any school, guest artists generate excitement.  Students get inspired and pay attention. I will work alongside ANIM's faculty to give private lessons and coach small groups but I will also contribute my own expertise in jazz and rock styles, improvisation and cross-cultural collaboration.
  • ANIM’s faculty is dedicated, working long hours in artistic as well as administrative roles. My residency will provide a break in a teacher's busy schedule, adding new pedagogical and artistic perspectives and allowing ANIM's faculty to attend to other areas of professional and institutional development.
  • Travel to Afghanistan can pose a logistical and financial challenge to potential guest artists; one of the goals of my visits to ANIM is to create a culture of international engagement at NEC and carve a pathway for my extended community of students and colleagues to engage in this type of work, at ANIM and beyond.

What We Need & What You Get

The New England Conservatory is sponsoring the cost of my travel to Kabul, and I am donating my time and services to ANIM. Now, I am raising funds cover my costs for 15 days on the ground. The cost of a secure guest house, meals and local transportation comes to about $100/day, so my first funding target is $1500. I’ll be traveling to Kabul whether or not I make this goal.

 

I would also like to raise funds to sponsor the education for at least of ANIM’s students. An annual stipend of $360 keeps a child in school and off the streets. So, my goal in all is $1860. Any surplus funds will go to endow additional scholarships.


Every little bit helps, so I do hope you'll contribute. I’ve concocted some little rewards to thank you for your generosity. Please look them over and give as generously as you can. Thank you.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you’re in the Boston area, come to “Music From the Front Pages”, a benefit concert at the Lily Pad in Cambridge on Monday, July 18, 2011. For more information visit the NEC in Afghanistan blog.
  • Spread the word on Facebook and Twitter. Post this event to your Facebook wall. Send an email out to your friends.
  • Get a group going in your office, music studio or classroom: set the goal of raising the cost to sponsor a child for an entire year.

story:
Give Japanese children a chance to express what they feel and think after the nuclear disaster. Support them telling and sharing their stories, experiences, and opinions on TV!


Our Story

Even at this moment, every hour, 2 hundred million bq. of radioactive substances are continuously being emitted from the Fukushima Daiichi nuclear plant. There are more than 300.000 children living in areas with the same level of radioactive pollution as in the evacuation zone of Chernobyl. The radioactive substance, which are supposed to be confined, have now spread across the entire country through ashes, rubble and food. With the children being vulnerable to dangerous radiation, what is their opinion about the current situation?

The ongoing program ï¿½ContActï¿½ aired at Cabel-TV Asahi New Star, will appear as a special 2hour program. This program will be aired sometime early in January 2012. Ourplanet-TV wants to produce a program focusing on children and various citizens, who will be participating in the broadcast. The feature will include students from elementary to high school, who are living in Fukushima and the Kantou region (Northeastern Japan) as well. The students will be collecting their own data regarding nuclear radiation from researchers and nuclear power plants. In 5 to 10 years from now, what will the causes of the damaging radiation be? And what will happen to nuclear energy policies? The children will be questioning their own future. Ourplanet-TV is going to make the first Japanese public access program from the perspective of the children.

Background

Even after the tragic accident on March 11th, at the Fukushima nuclear power plant the government and TEPCO continued to underestimate and underreport the severity of the accident and the potential effects on the surrounding population. The media followed this lead by not questioning the information they were getting from the government and TEPCO and simply passed along what they were being told, always telling the best case scenario. In the last 6 months Ourplanet-TV has been covering the whole incident and given transparent information about the incident as opposed to the mass media. For parents living close to the nuclear incidents epicenter, it has been crucial for them to have access to objective information regarding the disastrous situation.

The program will focus on the Japanese children, who has been affected by the Fukushima nuclear incident. These children are exposed to radioactivity everyday and has their everyday life centered around this incident. The children's parents are struggling to get their children evacuated to a place were they are less exposed to radioactivity. The case has been taken to a court, but still more than a half year later nothing has changed. The children living close to the epicenter of the nuclear plant still cannot play in the school yards and outside their houses without being exposed to radiation.

The Impact

By giving a donation to the program, we will be able to broadcast a program that documents the children's daily life and how they have been affected by the nuclear incident. We would like to give them a chance to express what they feel and what they think and tell their stories, experiences, and opinions to the society.  

What is OurPlanetTV?

Ourplanet-TV is a NGO, which began its activities in 2001. As an alternative non-profit and non-commercial media station, Ourplanet-TV has been producing independent documentary films & interviews and has been broadcasting the content online. Ourplanet-TV adopts a non-profit and non-commercial management style, so we do not have any advertisement costs and all our production expenses is covered by membership fees and donations from individuals. We are highly independent from any political or commercial affiliation. 


Budget

The 2 hour special broadcast requires more production cost than usual. We would like to collect donations from people who sympathizes with the content of our special program. With your support our goal is to raise $ 2500 which will cover the following;

Transportation cost / Costs for interviews / Studio Expenses /Editing Videos /Promotion

story:
Our Story

       New Planet Media Studio tells stories that affect us all about environmental issues that mainstream media doesn't cover. By  crafting riveting scripts and revealing video, the Studio team is able to inspire people to take actions that make a real difference.

      Albert Einstein said, “we can’t solve problems by using the same kind of thinking we used when we created them.” Our ways of doing business limit our ability to live sustainably. Yet we can’t throw out our economy nor pretend our limited resources will support us.  We need new ideas to develop new ways of working. New Planet Media Studio covers stories on sustainability issues that impact society, business, finance and nature around the world. Through video, educational story lines, research, statistics and compelling presentation of all sides of the issue, our stories drive people to act.

       Stories reveal the ripple effect of how small actions create big reactions that affect all manner of people regardless of location, economic standing or political stripe. From the inspirational to the educational to the alarming, we aim to educate those who want to make a difference. By exposing people to engaging perspectives we catalyze opportunities with new ideas, models and success stories we never learn about from mainstream media. 

The Impact

 

New Planet Media Studio co-founder Leigh Badgley's film "Making a Stand" about a Greenpeace Argentina's campaign to stop the de-forestation of an ancient forest reserve in Argentina that was destroying the home of the Wichi indigenous people, helped attract so much publicity that, the President of Argentina submitted to the pressure and called a moratorium on any further encroachment or de-forestation. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

     We would like to raise funds to produce our first video product. The first project of New Planet Media Studio is an educational video series entitled "Whole Earth Dialogue" that shows kids and adults that before you make changes, it's better to understand how the world works first. Then the series presents useful pragmatic action steps. There are two parts to the series, a 6 video starter project and the remainder of 24 videos to complete the 30 video set.

 

     In 30 three minute video presentations, Rex Weyler (journalist, econolist, Greenpeace International co-founder and author teams ups with Jon Cooksey, award-winning filmmaker, screen writer of the world's funniest global warming film "How to Boil a Frog", to explain society's environmental challenge by showing how the world really works. 

     By using real story telling, not lectures, using images, music, feelings and real people, Weyler and Cooksey will establish the series' foundation to describe the systems, ecology, economics, time, human experience, and genuine solutions that are often at odds with nature. What does it really mean to achieve sustainability? In the opening of the series the viewer will join in the search for the very elements of great solutions that are not available from the mainstream media or our education system. Supporting material will link viewers to critical information. The filmmakers also meet and interview some of the top thinkers and visionaries in these topics who are putting vital new ideas to work. They are the people we never get to hear about who are leading the charge for true sustainability.

Project Budget

   This project has two parts. The full project is 30 videos. The first part has 6 three minute videos. The second part completes the 30 video series and provides funding for promotion.

    These six videos comprise a Summary of Human habitation in an Ecological world. The introductory videos reveal the essentials of Ecology, Economy, Time, Growth, Feelings, and Solutions. Part two covers the Solutions, People & Politics, Systems & Ecology, Ecological Economics, Nature of Energy, Eco-Psychology - or how environmental trauma effects us all. Part two then profiles ecology's visionaries; people like John Stuart Mill, the first Ecological Economist, Albert Bartlett on the Math of Growth, Kathy McMahon on Peak Oil, and Anita Burke discussing sustainability inside the oil company boardroom.

 

 Individual 3-minute video segments, with graphics and production costs: $3,300 to $6,700 each

 == Full Budget Total: $240,000

      Thirty 3-minute videos: $180,000 - $195,000

      90-minutes of film in 3-minute user-friendly bite-sized, entertaining, Internet videos.

      plus launch promotion budget, social networking, website: $45,000.

== Typical 3-minute video Production budget: The Video budgets vary. Some costs are well below commercial production standards due to support from film industry colleagues, volunteer technicians, and services offered at low cost, made available by Producer Jon Cooksey. All video projects will range in cost between the two scenarios presented in the budget: $3,350 to $6,750.

 

PER VIDEO                                          medium production   /    low cost

 

Script development/writing/research            $   750                  $   200

Camera & sound rental                                            600                       250

Producer fees, expenses (reduced)                       600                      300

Camera & sound people (1-2 days)                    1,400                    1,000

Editing system rental (with software)                  250                       250

Editor (2-4 days)                                                        600                       300

Static graphics                                                           400                       200

Video graphics/animation                                   1,800                       600

2 terabyte Hard drive (amortized)                          50                         50

Travel, expenses                                                        300                       200

 

TOTAL                                                                    $6,750                   $3,350

                                                                                 ======                ======

 

So what do you get if you come along for the ride? We have designed some super perks for being one of our funders. And remember, this is just the beginning. We have a lot more projects in the pipeline. We will be applying to foundations to fund the development of the entire studio to support the 20 additional projects that we have in development. 

Want to be part of the beginning of a film studio! This is it, the ground floor: we want you to experience helping make change happen. When you become part of something that makes a difference, you feel happier about everything in life. Please join us and decide what kind of Donor you want to be.

 What will we do if we can't raise all the funds? We will make Part 1 of the series, the first 6 three minute videos ($39,000 needed) and hope that the quality of the messages in this project will attract more funding to complete the full 30 video series.

Other Ways You Can Help

How can you help New Planet Media Studio launch? Put this Indiegogo link on your Facebook page. Send out a Twitter message and link to your friends. Go to www.AWISH.net to see the documentary that started this studio. Blog about it. Tell your friends that you want to know the real story about sustainability so you can find out what you can really do about it and stop thinking that recycling and light bulbs are going to change our future.

30 video series.
Other Ways You Can Help
How
can you help New Planet Media Studio launch? Put this Indiegogo link on your
Facebook page. Send out a Twitter message and link to your friends. Go to
www.AWISH.net to see the documentary that started this studio. Blog about it.
Tell your friends that you want to know the real story about sustainability so
you can find out what you can really do about it and stop thinking that
recycling and light bulbs are going to change our future.

story:
NOTE: Only use the payment instructions on this website for online payment via paypal.  If you would like to send a check instead (and most do), please email me at DCollins76@gmail.com for my address info.  THANKS!

Our Story

I am an activist in the progressive movement and am also a single mother.  Often, I get involved in campaigns or community issues that my sons are just learning about, and therefore, have a difficult time relating to. 


This year I received a scholarship to go to Netroots Nation 2011.  It includes panels led by national and international experts; identity, issue and regional caucuses; prominent political, issue and policy-oriented speakers; a progressive film screening series; and the most concentrated gathering of progressive bloggers to date.


The scholarship covers my expenses, but I need help bringing my sons, the Collins Boys, with me. 


The Impact

I teach them about commitment to community through my own activities.   But hey, when it comes to teenagers - "That's just momma doing her momma thing."  The exposure they will receive at Netroots Nation will be an experience of a lifetime.  By helping me bring Daylin and Chauncey to Netroots Nation in Minneapolis, MN this June, you give them an opportunity to learn from a wildly diverse group of progressive activist who contribute to the movement in various ways: bloggers, political pundits, community organizers, web developers, politicians, and more.  They will also be exposed to a wide array of progressive issues: environmental, social and economic justice; immigration; equitable education; workers' rights; and more.


And there is a Youth Caucus!  How powerful is that?  To see your peers fired up for change and making things happen! 


What We Need & What You Get

I received a scholarship for myself which covers the event registration and the hotel expense for my half of a room.  We need funding for

  • the other half of the hotel expense $210 (half of $140 x 3 nights)
  • round trip travel $700 (road trip cost: $500 gas + $200 over night stay // or estimated flight expense $800 - the Collins Boys prefer to fly.  So if we exceed our minimum fund-raising goal of $1070, we will fly!)
  • and food $160 (4 days and 3 nights).


You can follow us on our journey as we share our conference experience, including the travel adventure to get there and back as we post live Twitter feeds, Twit-pics, and Facebook updates! @DDCollins76


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word and share this fund-raising project!  It's for the kids! (smile)

story:
"Literary education must follow the education of the hand —the one gift that distinguishes man from beast.” - Mahatma Gandhi

UPDATE (12/13/12): 

We've been completely overwhelmed with gratitude for the amazing response we've received in less than 48 hours! I'm speechless. THANK YOU! As we surpass our goal, let's keep this campaign going! With additional funding, we will purchase the following materials to expand our technological resources and to open the cultural lab to a music education workshop program, with the help and support from mentors in the U.S. and India who will help us in developing a curriculum: 
  • an electronic keyboard, CD player, speaker set (approx. $150)
  • Indian instruments: a sitar, tambura, and tabla (approx. $150)
  • a computer for the lab to use with the projector (used: approx. $100; new: approx. $200)
  • music education teacher training (approx. $100)
  • music books and CDs (approx. $100)
  • funding for postage costs for an art pen pal exchange program with an international school (approx. $80 for one year for four standards)
  • any additional funding will be allocated for art and music teacher training program for new teachers in future years, the museum/gallery visit fund, and more library books! 

THANK YOU from the bottom of our hearts for your support! We will continue to send updates! Happy Holidays! 

--

THE SITUATION

While art education programs may be struggling to survive across the U.S., they are almost nonexistent in the low-income education sector in Hyderabad, India. Here at Alliance International, a low-cost private school that serves students from underprivileged families, we are trying to change that. Recognizing that every child deserves access to books and art classes to foster creativity, develop critical thinking skills, and explore the world beyond classroom walls, we want to provide all 1,300 students at Alliance with a multipurpose cultural laboratory that will serve as an art classroom, library, and reading space for years to come.

My name is Kelsey Coates, I am an IDEX Fellow in Social Enterprise, and I serve as the manager of the new Alliance Art Education Program (AAEP). This past year, we have initiated art classes to students through school-wide workshops, competitions, and an empathy-based art curriculum that I designed for students from 5th-8th standards. While these projects have been well received by students, the current classrooms at Alliance are too cramped for art classes. In most rooms, four students sit on one bench, leaving little space for girls and boys to paint, sculpt, and draw openly and comfortably. Also, without a projector, art textbooks, or a color printer, we have been unable to show art works to students for inspiration and discussion purposes. 

The school would like to increase its outreach by providing regular, weekly art classes to students from 1st - 9th standards during study hours next year. I am currently in the process of training teachers in art education and have facilitated a partnership with the Hyderabad-based Daira Center for Arts and Culture to seek programmatic support. I am also arranging a mentorship program with a high-income private school in Hyderabad to establish a working relationship between trained art teachers and new AAEP teachers at Alliance.

The school is also in need of a library and reading space. Last year, management at Alliance procured 400 books through Pratham Books (http://prathambooks.org/), but without a reserved library space, students have been unable to use them as much as they would like.

The new cultural laboratory will address all of these needs. As manager of the AAEP, I will ensure programmatic sustainability by training and guiding teachers and school management in using the lab regularly while keeping normal class times. We aim to build the lab in mid- to late February to begin using the lab as soon as possible and to officially launch new programming in July 2013. 

WHAT WE NEED

Alliance has reserved a large classroom that it will devote to the cultural laboratory, but we need assistance in furnishing the space and purchasing books and art supplies. More specifically, we are requesting donations for the following: 

  • a projector to display art works that will serve as inspiration to students during art lessons 
  • 6 foldable tables and 30 chairs that give students space to draw, sculpt, paint, and create
  • bookshelves to house the new library collection, with a slidable plastic covering to protect books during art classes
  • approx. 1,000 books, to be purchased from local vendors and education service providers, at roughly 50 cents each
  • librarian training in implementing reading logs, assessing student reading levels, and assigning reading activities
  • beanbags and colorful foam flooring to make the room a comfortable reading space when not in use as an art classroom
  • a sink (with construction costs), for students to wash hands and art supplies in between classes
  • laminated art posters to provide additional inspiration
  • solar powered lighting fixtures to provide ample light during regular power outages
  • additional art supplies not provided by students: clay, paints, paintbrushes
  • remaining funds will go to a Museum/Gallery Visit Fund, so Alliance can take students on field trips to see local art outside of Golconda

The estimated total of these supplies is $1,500. Books will be purchased from the following Indian vendors, in addition to local shops: 

  • National Book Trust  http://www.nbtindia.gov.in/
  • Children’s Book Trust  http://www.childrensbooktrust.com/
  • Cambridge University Press  http://cambridgeindia.org/
  • Tulika Books  http://www.tulikabooks.com/
  • Sterling Books http://www.sterlingbookhouse.com/

As previously noted, the Children's Gallery at the Daira Center for Arts and Culture in Hyderabad (https://www.facebook.com/DairaGallery) has graciously agreed to provide support to Alliance as the school launches the AAEP. Daira will guide Alliance art teachers in lesson planning in addition to sponsoring workshop events and gallery showings for the students. 

THE IMPACT 

Alliance is a student-focused institution and currently directs the bulk of its disposable funds to the Mother Sogra Educational Trust (MSET), a student scholarship fund. School fees are low, ranging from approximately $6 - $11 a month per student, to ensure that the school addresses the low-income community in Golconda, Hyderabad.  Although the school operates with a progressive approach to technology and cultural education, the school administration cannot finance additional building projects at this time. 

Alliance maintains a standard of excellence in the community and is expanding to 1,600 students in the next year. By contributing to this project, you will have the opportunity to contribute to both the welfare of Alliance students in the underserved Golconda communtiy as well as the overall Affordable Private School (APS) movement that is thriving in Hyderabad and beyond as a model for education development. 

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Every small donation is greatly appreciated and will leave a life-long impact on students at Alliance International. Please share this campaign with family and friends via email, Facebook, or Twitter. 

If you would also like to donate to the student scholarship fund at Alliance, please contact me via email at kelsey.coates@idexfellows.com and I will send you more information. 

Thank you so much for all of your support! I will update all of you as the project comes to fruition! 

Kelsey

story:
My name is Alison Parker and I am a professional costumier.

Here's what my project, ricRACK, is about.

I am organizing costume clinics for kids for Halloween this year.  I am seeking donations of used costume pieces and costume tools (i.e. sewing machines) that will be distributed to community centers throughout New Orleans.  With the support of staff and volunteers, children will learn to recycle, alter or build their own costume using these donations.  My  mission is to teach kids new skills and give them the opportunity to be creative with their costumes.
-- We have identified key neighborhoods in New Orleans and engaged community centers to become locations for our costume clinics.  We are working closely with the Freret Neighborhood Center, the Junior League, and Neighborhood Housing Serivces to coordinate these efforts.

-- We are currently campaigning for donated costumes, sewing supplies, accessories and other costume items from regional theaters,  rental houses, costume supply and industry wholesalers from around the nation.  They can  ship us their donations using our account with UPS or on their own accord. Because we are already relying on their generosity to give us their costumes and supplies, we can not assume they also will want to pay to ship to us. 

SHIPPING  WILL BE THE BIGGEST EXPENSE WE WILL INCUR. WE APPROXIMATE THIS EXPENSE TO BE FROM $2500-$3500.

An example of who we would want to donate to us:

www.postandcourier.com/article/20120612/PC16/120619769/spoleto-cleaning-out-closet-and-giving-away-years-of-opera-costumes

--Neighborhood Housing Services is our fiscal sponsor.  Being spnsored by a non profit organization allows us to offer businesses that donate to us a tax deduction for donations. 

--Here is a link to news footage of the annual Great Costume Giveaway done at the Freret Neighborhood Center.  Our hope is to continue this tradition, but take out the word "FREE" (as in costume), and replace it with "repurposed and altered".

http://news.yahoo.com/video/neworleanswdsu-23824923/freret-street-neighborhood-center-hosts-another-successful-halloween-party-27101426.html#crsl=%252Fvideo%252F

  -- With your donations, we also will be able to rent a space and the equipment needed to gather and catalogue all donated items, as well as, organize all materials and prepare them for distribution to each Community Partner site.  Our goal is to collect 28 racks of costumes and supplies.  We would like to be able to deliver 4 racks of costume goodness and 2 sewing machines to each center.

IT COSTS $35 PER RACK/ PER MONTH.

SO, $35 X 2 MONTHS X 28 RACKS= $1960

WE APPROXIMATE ALL OTHER MISC SEWING SUPPLIES @$1500

--HOLLYWOOD TRUCKS LLC has generously donated the use of a cube truck and driver for the day to deliver all the racks...SAVINGS $500!!

--OUR WAREHOUSE SPACE IS $400/MONTH...$1200!

--The clinics will take place the weekend before Halloween, October 21 and 22.  Each center will be staffed with one professional costumer and 4 volunteers.

--We will be soliciting the donation of sewing machines from a large manufacturer, such as Singer or Brother.  All supplies or machines will then be left at each community center and be available for use at the centers discretion.

--If you would like to donate costumes, supplies, etc to us, as well as funding, please reply to ricracknola@gmail.com, with "donate costumes" in the subject line.

In the grandest grand scheme of things, it is our vision to see the city with the greatest costume culture flourish.  We want New Orleans to be remembered in the hearts and minds of it's visitors, not only as the food capital, but also the costume capital of the country.

In the event, we should raise more funds than budgeted, we will campaign for more costume donations, rent a bigger space, and find other neighborhoods where we can hold our costume clincs.

As a one (wo)man organization right now, I most graciously and humbly would like to thank dean jordan, Barbara Hause, Jenna McRae and Eden Miller for their advice and support.

story:
A tragedy is unfolding before us. While school enrolment is rising in India, education standards are falling — girls especially are disproportionately dropping out from school.

Help us put more girls from disadvantaged backgrounds into quality schools.

We believe educating girls is the necessary first step a family can take to emerge from poverty.

We also want to shift the emphasis towards quality of education.

Many educational non-profits in India already do great work. We work with them to put girls not just through school, but through good, low-cost private schools near their homes.

Gyanada Foundation is a new NGO based in Singapore. We do not run schools, far less build them ourselves.

We partner with, and support, these existing non-profits on the ground in India — next to those slums where the full benefit of a rising economy has not reached.

We work in Ranchi, Delhi, Mumbai and Kolkata.

 

What We Need

For as little as US$149, or $12.50 a month, you'll get to put one girl through quality private schooling in Delhi, Mumbai, Ranchi or Kolkata.

In the academic year beginning April 2013, we'll put 150 girls through school — half of this we'll try to raise here, the other half we'll try to raise from private donors in Singapore and the US.

  • For $149 a year, put 1 girl from a disadvantaged background in India through a whole year of school
  • Get updated on her academic progress
  • For $49, support our Right to Quality Education For the Girl Child campaign, run by us and our partner organizations so we can advocate to improve on existing Right to Education laws to ensure gender equity and teacher accountability
  • Support as many girls as you can! You can choose to support 5 girls a year for US$699, or less than $12 a month, or enter any amount you prefer

Even if we don't hit our target of $8500, we'll use everything we raise to support as many girls as we can.

How We'll Do This

We help these organisations select disadvantaged local girls, and send them to private schools in the area. Poor parents want their girls to go to these schools and not “free” state schools because many government teachers do not turn up, and when they do — they produce the same or worse student outcomes. But many parents are so poor that they cannot send all their children to these low-cost private schools – and often end up sending only their boys.

We want to humbly extend a small but helping hand to these families. Help us do that.

We'll keep you in our Indiegogo donors' mailing lists so we can update you on how we're doing, how the funds are being disbursed, and let you know how the girl you've supported is doing academically through the school year. 

We would also love if you could help us by 

  • Telling your friends about us
  • Sharing this across your social and real life networks
  • Sending emails with a link to this campaign, to your friends, family and anyone who'd be interested in helping

We would also love if you could help us by 

Telling your friends about us
Sharing this across your social and real life networks
Sending emails with a link to this campaign, to your friends, family and anyone who'd be interested in helping

story:
Summary

Multiple researches show that only one in seven people are happy with their professional life. Only one in four find jobs related to the major they graduated within college.

In addition, one in two people that graduate from college are unemployed or working on jobs that do not require a bachelor's degree.

It is a problem affecting 157 million Americans who are part of the workforce today, aggravated by the 17 million people enrolling in college every year.

Tuition costs continue to rise, fueling the 1.7 trillion dollars accumulated student debt in the United States. Today, this amount is $740 billion higher than the total credit card debt in the nation.

At NeoCare, we believe there is a better way to choose, plan and pursue a professional career.

We also believe the professional journey should be flexible and allow for constant adjustments, including a complete pivot should it become the best option forward. 

We are building a digital platform to help people select a career and be guided through their journey, providing mentorship 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

Our team at NeoCare has over 15 years of experience helping companies find suitable candidates for their positions. 

We do this by applying modern evaluation techniques that profile the open positions and help identify the most compatible candidates to fill them. 

The Impact

The NeoCare platform will launch in the United States as part of the counseling instruments available to high schools.

We expect to reach 17 thousand mentees this year and 55 thousand until December of next year. 

Our objective is to help 1.6 million professionals in 71 countries by 2025.

Currently, 43% of students graduate from college, and only 5% complete their courses on time. 

At NeoCare, we believe our platform can increase college completion to 78%.

We also think it can slow the growth of student loans with the potential to avoid 422 billion dollars in new debts by 2025.
