story:
iTribe ...

was implemented by the Christopher Robert Project and represents an innovative approach to teaching English to non-English speakers.

Relying on the direction of our  knowledgeable field project manager and his heavy duty Ford truck, we are able to go where few dare. Our job? To deliver the power of the English language to the most remote villages utilyzing tablet pcs, whiteboards, pencils and teachers. iTribe's credo is not only to educate but also to give students the confidence, creativity and leadership skills necessary to create their own legacy in an ever changing high tech English speaking world.

iTribe is simple and effective in it's purpose. The power of the English language will remove barriers of social mobility the indigenous hill tribes of northern Thailand face. The program also grants access to information technology which will facilitate self-determined village development.

iTribe's mission is not only English landuage education but also to combat the socio-economic inequalities faced by the hill tribe demographic by expanding the way villagers view possibilities for themselves and their communities. Our multicultural team and the hill tribe communities we support believe strongly in the potential of language and technology but more importantly we understand that a reciprocal exchange of knowledge and ideas is integral to our program’s success and widespread social coordination.

 

WHAT YOUR $ DOES …

$12,000 will fund iTribe in the village of Mae Jok for 3 months

  • ANY CONTRIBUTION
    • IS IMPORTANT TO US! In Thailand a little goes a long way and any donation is meaningful, necessary and effectively moves us closer to our goal of producing powerful individuals who are able to help themselves and their communities

  • $50 pays for teaching supplies

    • This money goes towards whiteboards, mats, markers, pencils, paper etc. and all the supplies necessary for volunteer teachers to effectively run informal classrooms in the jungle

  • $100 pays for iPad accessories

    • Military Spec. cases are necessary given the nature of our outdoor classrooms where dirt, mud and weather are all uncontrollable variables. We also rely heavily on headphones to create privacy in the learning process and minimize external noise from cowbells and chickens.

  • $200 pays for a 3 day village visit

    • We use this time to run classes using traditional teaching alongside technology and run informal tech sessions with villagers. Additionally, we rely on the community for food, accommodation and support so this money stimulates the local village economy and provides security for the communities that grant us the privilege to work with them.

  • $500 pays for 1 iPad

    • We believe that every student deserves to interact with the learning process peacefully and exempt from judgment. The project therefore necessitates 1 iPad for each student so that they may engage with tablet technology and educational apps. independently and without external distraction.

BIG PICTURE

Without iTribe hill tribe individuals living in the village have to seek education outside the village, especially past primary school. This courage and aspiration for education is rewarded with long travel times, discrimination and limited employment options. The opportunities that are available to hill tribe members are not accurate representations of this group’s incredible untapped potential. Its time village members were imbued with the confidence to realize their capabilities and given the tools to do great things for themselves, their communities, their country and the world.

No one deserves to be left behind so iTribe seeks not only to bring this group out of the periphery of society and bridge the digital divide but also strives to change the paradigm of how education is provided to hill tribes. Hill tribe members no longer have to leave the village to get a quality education because we are bringing education to the village in order to help these communities realize their own power, strength and potential.

WE LOVE SUPPORT

If you are not in a position to donate please like our Facebook page and shoot us a message if you are interested in learning more or donating of your time. Thank you so much in advance for your help!

https://www.facebook.com/#!/thecrproject?fref=ts

Sincerely,

The CRProject team

story:
My Story

 

I reached my goal of a Masters Degree in Education at age 65.  Now I want to pay forward by teaching music to Elders.

After returning home from Vietnam in 1969 I discovered that I had a passion for helping others reach their dreams.  I began teaching in the Military because I had first hand experiences to contribute to the safety of those to follow me.

As a civilian, I needed credentials to teach in the civilian sector, so I completed an AA in Electronics, a BA in Business and finally pulled all my teaching years together and completed a Masters in Education Adult Education and Administration.

Now, I wish to used this degree to work with Senior Citizens to create a music program to keep their minds and hands active.   But my student loans are keeping me from doing this, as I need to work more to pay them off.

A little help from each of you will make a huge difference in many lives!

What I Need & What You Get

I need to begin paying back student loans in February 2014, and funds to develop the Seniors training programs.  You can help me give to Senior Citizens thereby fulfilling a social and personal need to help the elderly.

The Impact

Seniors who are participating in their community in a social way.

Other Ways You Can Help

Volunteer at senior center within your community.

story:
About Me

  • My name is Megan O'Gara. I am currently a senior at Plymouth State University, snuggled up in the White Mountains, affectionately known as "New Hampshire's Playground." I grew up in New Hampshire, originally from Lebanon, and am in love with the Granite State. I am finishing up my degree in early childhood education, with a focus in teacher certification for grades K-3. I am deeply passionate about the importance of primary education, and hope to continue my studies in the field. 
  • For me, continuing my education will mean several things. The most important of which will be the ability to expand my knowledge. I have an interest in researching race and ethnicity conflicts in the early childhood classroom, advocacy issues for families from unique cultural backgrounds, and the importance of early education on the federal level, connecting political science and the topic of early childhood. 
  • Contributors to my campaign will help me achieve my goal of being a professional, intelligent, passionate, and informed leader in education. The first step to this goal is to master the Graduate Requirement Exam and apply to schools. 

What is Needed & What You Get

I'll break it down for you.

  • GRE examination fee: $115
  • PRAXIS II examination fee: $115
  • Harvard University Application Fee: $85
  • UPenn Application Fee: TBD
  • City College of New York Application Fee: TBD
  • Wheelock College Application Fee: TBD
  • Seattle University Application Fee: TBD
  • If I don't entirely reach my goal, the funds will supply my PRAXIS II exam, then my GRE exam, and then the application fee for Harvard University. 

The Impact

  • Contributing to this project will help me become a better world citizen. Going to graduate school will expand my knowledge and help me build powerful life skills to become a leader in the reform of education and the inclusion of families in the classroom. Your contribution will be helping a hardworking college student achieve goals and work to make her dreams come true. 
  • I've worked with countless school and community organizations to raise money for various efforts. From People to People Ambassador Trips to Music Organization Spaghetti Dinners, raising money effectively and purposefully is something that I take seriously. This effort is a beast of its own. I am raising this money single handedly for something that I want, something that I need, something that is essential for my career preparation and success in the field of education. 
  • Every contribution is appreciated. From a simple Facebook "share" to a donation of any size, recognizing the importance of an advanced education and how it will help me grow as a leader and reformer is a gift I cannot be more grateful for.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign!
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to share my site on the social media website of your choice. 

And that’s all there is to it.

story:
Camp Ohana Foundation

Our Mission: We are dedicated to providing underprivileged children and youth with high quality cross-cultural educational camp programs that encourage personal growth, enhance self-esteem and foster meaningful and lasting interpersonal relationships in a communal and nurturing environment.

Our Motto:

  • "Hakuna Matata" 
  • "Ohana means family, & family means nobody gets left behind"

"Raise this Roof"

The reason why I am reaching out to you through this platform is to raise awareness and money for our "Raise this Roof" campaign.  Education is extremely important, and in addition to building a new roof and rehabilitating our clubhouse into the first Children's Library in Western Kenya, the money will be used to provide books, paper, materials needed for them to learn and build on cognitive development, creativity, leadership, and team work. Help me reach that goal! 

Why We Need Your Help

We provide multiple programs for families and children at Camp Ohana Village and Campus.  Our programs include:

  • Health & Wellness Clinics
  • Clean Water Project
  • Cultural Experience
  • Wildlife & Environment Defenders
  • Recreation Programs - Girls/Boys Soccer 
  • Agricultural Program

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have the funds, don't worry! But, passing this message along would be great. Check our our website & facebook page:

  • http://www.campohana.org/
  • https://www.facebook.com/CampOhana

Sometimes just being aware and passing it on is the best gift of all.  Thank you for your time and reading all this information.  Mahalo!

story:
Our Goal

The goal of the Festival of Conscious Parenting is to share the awareness practices of the world’s spiritual traditions so that kids can grow up more emotionally healthy, resilient and whole, and less traumatized than the vast majority of adults.  We seek to make the world a better place, one moment with one child at a time. 

The Festival Plan   

The Festival will feature teachers and practitioners of diverse spiritual traditions, with inspiring and informative lectures, panels, rituals, break-out groups, and various activities.  It will take place June 20-22, 2014 at the Sonoma Country Day School campus, which includes the Jackson Theater, in Santa Rosa, California.  Friday evening and Saturday will be for adults; Sunday will bring the whole family together with activities for both children and adults. 

What is Conscious Parenting?

Conscious parenting is the process by which adults grow ever more effective at maintaining nurturing, loving contexts consistently for all the children in their lives.  All of us have the experience of intending to act with love and generosity, only to find ourselves unconsciously expressing the fears and traumas that shaped us.  If we can stop “the sins of the fathers” from being passed onto the next generation, how could the world be healed?  How much healing can we create? Note that conscious parenting is not just for those currently raising children, but for ALL adults who interact with children, including grandparents, family, educators, friends, etc. 

The Opportunity of Conscious Parenting

The Festival seeks to share techniques, ideas and inspiration that will celebrate and reinforce EVERY instance when we might have judged a child by some harsh external standard, and instead offer love, nurturance and guidance without an unconscious agenda. Thus conscious parenting is an opportunity to create happiness for all; it is not yet another expectation of perfection from adults, which would only compound suffering.  Moreover, as we adults become more consistently, lovingly present for children, we will be empowered to treat one another with love and respect too.

Help Our Volunteers Create the Festival!

We need your help to make the Festival a reality!  There is no paid staff; the project is entirely created and supported by volunteers from many spiritual traditions.  Check out the Festival website at www.festivalofconsciousparenting.org to find out more about who we are, and more about what the Festival will offer. 

How Will We Use Your Donation:

To start, we need money for the following tasks:

  • to put down a deposit on the venue

  • to create publicity and get the word out

  • for other necessary project tasks 

DONATE GENEROUSLY!  Help us to get this show on the road!

Donation Incentives

Check out the various incentives that we’re creating to encourage your generosity:

  • $25 – Name acknowledgment in the Festival program

  • $50 – Name acknowledgment, plus a 2014 Festival of Conscious Parenting wall calendar

  • $100 – All the above, plus either a Festival t-shirt, or a copy of Lee Lozowick’s book Conscious Parenting

  • $150 – All the above, plus BOTH a Festival t-shirt and a copy of Lee Lozowick’s book Conscious Parenting

  • $200 – 2 Tickets to the Festival, plus all of the above, including both the book and the t-shirt

In addition to the incentives, donations are tax deductible because the Festival is being sponsored by Tayu Order, Incorporated, a nonprofit church incorporated in California.  Tayu Order has operated Tayu Meditation Center for over thirty years, and also operates Many Rivers Books & Tea in Sebastopol, California, a spiritual bookstore and tea shop (www.manyriversbooks.com).  The Tayu philosophy celebrates the contributions of all spiritual and religious traditions. 

Volunteer!

In addition to getting the word out, you can also volunteer to help with the many tasks that need doing to create a big public event.  Or maybe you are a spiritual practitioner, or know of one, who would like to suggest, or offer to lead a break-out group.  There are so many ways to help us make the dream of the Festival a reality!  Contact us via our website: http://www.festivalofconsciousparenting.org/contact-us-and-directions.html

story:
Short Summary

IIT (Institute for Information Technology) is the idea of Haitian, Lionel Legoute, who grew up in Les Cayes, Haiti. After serving with many mission teams from the United States, he had a dream to begin a computer school in his hometown to help train and educate others in his community so they can be productive and begin to build a better Haiti.

Education is key to helping the people of Haiti help themselves. Through this computer school, many who might not be able to attend college can receive valuable computer skills that would be useful to various businesses and institutions throughout the country.

Funding is channeled through US-based Haiti Mission Project (HMP) is a 501(c)(3) non-profit organization based in Minneapolis, Minnesota.  All donations ARE tax deductible!

With the partnership and initial funding from various donors in the U.S., this new school was setup in June 2012. Classes began in September!

What We Need

Due to the instability of the power grid in this part of Haiti, IIT needs a generator to ensure classes are conducted on schedule and without interruption.
 
100% of the contributions received above and beyond our funding goal will be used toward the subsidy of computer education to the students and are tax deductible.
 

The Impact & Reward

As a reward, you are directly contributing to the assistance of individuals in desperate need to enhance their standard of living.  Our team has heard from Corporate Foundations that have supported us that we are one of the success stories of their funding.  Corporate Foundation Leaders have been able to see the tangible results of their donations and have commented that while there is much funding continually flowing to third world countries, rarely is there such a direct positive outcome as there has been with setting up IIT.
 
The goal of IIT is to providing basic to intermediate computer training that would help students qualify for a job or a better job.

Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word!  Visit http://www.iithaiti.org

100% of the contributions received above and beyond our funding goal will be used toward the subsidy of computer education to the students and are tax deductible.
 

The Impact & Reward
As a reward, you are directly contributing to the assistance of individuals in desperate need to enhance their standard of living.  Our team has heard from Corporate Foundations that have supported us that we are one of the success stories of their funding.  Corporate Foundation Leaders have been able to see the tangible results of their donations and have commented that while there is much funding continually flowing to third world countries, rarely is there such a direct positive outcome as there has been with setting up IIT.
 
The goal of IIT is to providing basic to intermediate computer training that would help students qualify for a job or a better job.

Other Ways You Can Help
Spread the word!  Visit http://www.iithaiti.org

story:
Who We Are

Bay Area Mutual Aid (BAMA) is a a group of social workers committed to fighting for social justice in our communities, workplaces and society at large, by organizing and mobilizing social workers, supporting each other, and collaborating with other professionals, clients, and community stakeholders.  We apply a broad definition to the title “social worker” and seek to engage all those doing social work in its many forms. We believe that social change and social justice are integral to all forms of social work and hope to reinvigorate our field’s commitment to and understanding of “social change and social justice.” Instead of looking away from abuses of power, we seek to apply a critical understanding of power, privilege and oppression to our work.

What We Need & What You Get

On Saturday April 20th, 2013 BAMA will be hosting a dynamic, interdisciplinary, participatory forum focused on the idea of "Reimagining Social Work". We are expecting a crowd of 40-50 participants. We are seeking contributions to support the operating costs for the event including space rental, supplies, and food. BAMA is a volunteer-run organization and the forum will be open to all members of the community free of charge. By supporting this effort, you are supporting the growth and development of a critical, social justice-oriented movement within the social work community in the Bay Area. 

The Impact

While the NASW - CA Chapter and other mainstream social work organizations across the country are lobbying to protect the social work title and narrow the definition of who is a "social worker", BAMA is calling for a dialogue about how we can expand the definition and the practice of social work in our communities.  Through the sharing of critical histories and a collective process of visioning led by community leaders, this forum is an opportunity for folks to gather, discuss and develop alternatives to the more narrow, problematic, mainstream definitions of social work.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that times are tough and some of you may not be able to support the project financially, but that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  • Attend the Reimagining Social Work event. Register by emailing your name and contact info (phone # and email address) to reimaginingsocialwork@gmail.com.
  • Spread the word about Reimagining Social Work.
  • Forward information about this fundraising campaign to others who might be interested in donating and/or attending.
  • Join BAMA - visit the group website at http://bayareamutualaid.wordpress.com/ and / or attend one of our monthly meetings. See website for meeting dates and location.

story:
Heart of a Student Presents:

Heart of Brazil Tour - Changing Lives Worldwide

"You guys were amazing thanks for coming to my school you guys are the reason why I love this world people like you are like everybody should be! Your story hit home with me...I just want you guys to know that I found a place in my heart for you guys and you will always be there! When my kids grow up I want them to be able to experience what I did today. Thank you guys so much stay doing what you are doing because it really finds a way in people's hearts." - Iowa High School Student

"Today was the Best Day In Perry High School. Thanks For Making This A Day To Remember."

@Dante_Now @Brazilian2wins were definitely the best speakers Storm Lake has had in a long time. Thanks for the inspiration!

Probably the best assembly that I have gone to ever GreatMotivation 

@Brazilian2wins your story is AMAZING! nothing is impossible!

"Good speakers with great messages and a lot of talent huge thanks to  @HeartOFaSTUDENT"

 

The Brazilian Twins

Walter and Wagner Caldas grew up in the harsh realities of favela life in Rio de Janiero. Drugs and violence occupy the waking hours for those growing up in the ghettos of Brazil. Jonas Caldas, the Twins' father, pushed his sons to pursue a different path. Jonas, one of the only hand-violin makers in the country, introduced his sons to classical music. Instead of focusing on the sound of gun-fire, the Caldas brothers reached for the works of Bach and Mozart.

They were featured on National Public Radio and through a wild series of events, they ended up mastering English, receiving a full-ride music scholarship in the US and have been entertaining thousands with their charismatic persona, contagious energy and unique sound. Walter and Wagner have performed in New York, Los Angeles, Spain, Portugal and all over Iowa for audiences as young as 3 and as old as 90. 

 

 

 

Dante Means

 

Music has been a massive part of Dante Means' life. Means has performed at Carnegie Hall, opened for Ja Rule, and performed on 106 & Park - where he shattered records as an emerging artist. Recently, Dante served as a top recruiter for several state schools in Iowa. His impressive track record and innovative approach led him to design his own campaign around motivating students through entertainment to pursue their dreams. 

 

Heart of a Student

In less than 3 months, on a shoe-string budget, Heart of a Student gave an 11 high-school, 10,000 student tour in the state of Iowa and saw an amazing 25% sign up rate!

Walter and Wagner now have the incredible opportunity to return to Brazil with the Heart of a Student Message and show those in the very same shoes they were in, that there are other options in life. Society does not have to dictate your path. Nothing is Impossible.

Goal

There are over 6 million living in Rio de Janiero Brazil. For those living in the favelas, gun shots and drugs are commonplace. Growing up in poverty makes the drug trade appear incredibly enticing. Families struggle to put food on the table and the older kids of the neighborhood offer a fast thousand dollars, how could they say no?

The Heart of a Student Team is looking to change this outlook. We need to raise $26,400 to speak to over 22,000 Brazilian students (~$1/kid) over the course of five months from August - January.  [Certified Non-Profit]

What if we don't raise our goal?


Any lives impacted make a difference. We budgeted out this campaign to be as cost effective as possible without putting an unrealistic time frame associated with the project. We are operating on flex-funding so irregardless of if we go above or below our goal, we can impact as many kids as your contributions will allow. 

What if we raise more than our goal?

Because we will be operating on a limited stay in Brazil, funds raised above our goal will go towards funding the Heart of a Student: Heartland tour in the Midwest January 2014! We will then be able to give students college access all over the Midwest United States! We will close out Iowa then move to Minnesota, Illinois, Wisconisn, Nebraska and Missouri! Wherever there are students, we have a responsibility to motivate the next generation. Our youth are our future!!

Breakdown for Us and You!

We are operating as lean as possible!

  • $26,400
  • Travel for 6 (flight, visas, food): $12,200
  • Domestic Travel/lodging within Brazil: $2700
  • Documentary Equipment: $4,361
  • Sound equipment: $3,039
  • Crowdfunding Rewards, non-profit admin costs for grant: $2100
  • Slush fund (over runs, price jumps, emergencies) $2000
  • Also those involved will be opearting WITHOUT compensation

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute monetarily NO WORRIES! We still love you! Share our campaign with your friends and loved ones! 

SHARE SHARE SHARE SHARE :)

story:
We call on you to help us fund a delegation of young deaf Israelis who want to use their talents, experiences and achievements to help deaf children in Uganda.

During their time in Uganda, the group will volunteer in a number of local projects, including the Muse Uganda Arts School and Nazareth Kindergarten. Most significantly, they will participate in a local deaf youth camp run by local NGO Uganda National Association of the Deaf (UNAD), sharing their expertise by leading as well as participating in a number of sessions.

We strive to demonstrate that despite their disabilities these young people are able to not only receive help but also to give back to others. This is an opportunity to achieve two important goals: to help deaf children in the developing world, and to empower young deaf Israelis through the experience of giving.

The 4th Annual Uganda National Deaf Youth Camp

Deaf youth worldwide, and particularly in developing countries, remain a marginalized community, especially when it comes to education, employment and decision-making. It's against this background that Deaf Action Uganda is bringing together over 150 young deaf people in the 4th annual Uganda National Deaf Camp, with the aim of empowering them to become advocates and leaders who can create change in their community through education, networking, lobbying and advocacy.


The camp unites deaf youth from across the continent, giving them the opportunity to collaborate as a team, share their experiences and struggles, find solutions, and create change in their respective communities.

Meet the Delegation

The Israeli delegation to Uganda will consist of seven young deaf people from a wide range of professions such as basketball coaching, high school teacher, hydrotherapy therapist and students of theatre, physical education, industrial design and special needs education. Each of them has experience teaching deaf children, has worked with at-risk communities, and now wants to continue giving back to children in the developing world and in this way act as a role model for deaf youngsters in Israel.

Who We Are

The delegation is organized by three organizations:

  • The Association of the Deaf in Israel - a mutual-help association of the deaf and for the deaf.
  • Brit Olam - an Israeli volunteer organization which runs community-based development programs to reduce poverty and vulnerability in developing countries, as well as providing relief and rehabilitation projects in states of humanitarian crises.
  • Deaf Action Uganda - Advocates for human rights, sign language and access to quality services such as education and health services for deaf people.

What We Need

The group have worked very hard to raise most of the funds needed for the trip - and we just need that final push to make it a reality. Please give what you can so that these special young people can empower young Ugandans and themselves benefit from the act of giving.

What You Get

Apart from the feel-good factor, our perks include a range of unique sign language themed gifts, including special signing 'hamsas', a traditional symbol of good luck, personalized signs with your name written in sign language and a unique sign language clock.

                                  

* Photos and gifts from Siman Tov - http://www.simantov.co.il.

story: Hello potential savior of my childhood dream!  I am starting this fund raiser because my  tuition  to study abroad in Spain exceeds my financial aid by $1500, and am having to make two out of pocket payments to my program, taking any spending money I was going to have  over there away from me. Considering I already paid for my plane ticket and a $1000 dollar "good faith" payment, I'm beginning to get desperate to find whatever money I can get to make my one and only dream come true. Any money donated over the $1500 will allow me to have the trip of a lifetime! PLEASE, I urge you to hear my plea and find it within yourself to help a 22 year old college student make his dream come true!

story:
This fundraiser will help us fulfill our goal of traveling to Israel and Turkey over Winter Break. This trip is an amazing opportunity for us to learn about different cultures and experience parts of the world. As students at Whitman College, a small liberal arts school in eastern Washington, we have learned so much about diversity and cultural pluralism and we are ready to have our own experiences, however we need your help!

A Little Bit About Us

  • Lauren is a dog-loving scorpio and senior History-Art History double major! She is the Education Chair of her sorority, Kappa Kappa Gamma and hopes to write her senior thesis on Israeli architecture.
  • Emma is also a dog lover--an aquarius, though--and a sophomore Gender Studies-Rhetoric double major. She is a member of Alpha Phi and is on the marketing team.

We hope that you will consider donating to our campaign to help make our dreams of traveling the world a reality! Every penny counts and we appreciate your support.


xoxo

Lauren and Emma

story:
I am a doctoral candidate (Doctor of Business Administration) at Northcentral University, and anticipate beginning my doctoral research this September. While I have sufficient funding for tuition and fees, I will be incurring unanticipated expenses related to my research study.

My doctoral dissertation is entitled “Examining the Impact of Workplace Spirituality on Turnover Intention in the Food Service Industry”. Employee turnover in the restaurant industry is the highest of any U.S. industry (estimates range from 80% to over 100% annually). Employee turnover is difficult to measure until it has already happened, but turnover “intention” can be easily measured with a short survey. Workplace spirituality, or spirit at work, is a culture wherein an organization encourages meaning at work, connection with others, and a sense of community while at work. It is NOT religious in nature, and many organizations are not even aware that they promote this culture or atmosphere. Workplace spirituality has been demonstrated to produce positive benefits for both employers and employees, through increased productivity, reduced absenteeism, and reduced voluntary employee turnover.

My research study will examine the impact of workplace spirituality on employee turnover intention in the restaurant industry. Research study participants will be placed in two groups: a control group and an experimental group. Both groups will complete a survey at the beginning and the end of a ten-week period, about the level of workplace spirituality at their place of employment and their intent to look for employment. Survey responses would remain confidential and anonymous. The experimental group will participate in a series of four one-hour presentations covering the topic of workplace spirituality and the benefits for both employer and employee. The goal of my research is to determine if the implementation of a workplace spirituality intervention program impacts turnover intention among employees in food service organizations, and also between restaurant locations.

I will conduct my research with employees in multiple restaurant locations of a national chain whose identity will remain anonymous. In order to ensure a sufficient number of participants in each group, I will be compensating each participant $10 cash for each survey completed, and for each presentation attended.

My crowdfunding campaign goal is $4,000 based upon the following:

50 participants in control group X $10 per survey X two surveys = $1,000

50 participants in experimental group X $10 per survey X two surveys = $1,000

50 participants in experimental group X $10 per presentation X four presentations = $2,000

(The above amounts do not include travel and printing expenses which I am prepared to cover).  

In order to earn my doctorate, I  must complete my research regardless of whether or not I am successful in this fundraising campaign. The proceeds received by this crowdfunding campaign will reduce the amount of additional debt which I will incur in the completion of my degree.

NOTE: In order to prevent conflict of interest, any funds received from food service organizations, or employees or principals of the food service organization that is the subject of this study will be returned.

story:
This is what a family is supposed to, for the most part, look like... Well sans-myself.

This was my family during Easter of this year, 2014. I am not in this photo because I live in Japan as an ALT aka Assistant Language Teacher. Approximately 2 weeks after this photo I was diagnosed with pre-stage 1 cancer. I was planning to go home for a surprise visit during late summer. Unfortunately cancer sucks. Hospital visits to diagnose me, treatment, while good and effective, ate up my savings with doctors visits, surgery,being hospitalized and recovery. While recovering the day of my surgery, I found out that my brother, the one on the far left, suddenly was kicked out of our home, and up and disappeared into thin air. We know he's alive, and he's married some girl no one has ever met, and that's the only contact that my family has with him. I am beseeching you, friends, and some family, those who know are under an oath of secrecy, to please please help me make it home for Christmas. My goal is to raise of $950 but of course anything above and beyond would help greatly to curb bills while I'm gone because they will still be arriving while I am in America. I want to go home and do damage control and try to fix the broken parts of my family. I implore you to please help me however you can. Please give what you can. Something is better than nothing. I appreciate your consideration and am greatly thankful for all of you. Best!


Lance aka Joshua

story:
HOW IT ALL STARTED

My name is David Oliveras.  I've been a photographer and a filmmaker for many years.  I consider myself one of the luckiest guys around because I get to do what I love for a living.  I've always had a curiosity about the world and like to think I have an adventurous spirit.

Earlier this year, I went on a volunteer mission to Honduras with an organization that delivers medical and dental services to people living in remote, mountainous areas.  I volunteered my services as a photographer and interpreter and found the experience was transformative in a way I wasn't expecting.

I met a 13 year old boy named Roger (the youngest of 13).  After the recent death of his father, his family depended solely on his mother income from washing clothes.   He's in the third grade and dreams of coming to the United States and becoming a doctor.  Years earlier, another medical brigade performed some extensive surgery on him that corrected his badly malformed feet and allowed him to walk again. 

As a result his positive experience and the kindness he was shown, Roger became a bright, outgoing, selfless little boy.  I made up my mind that he deserved better and began sending his mother a small amount of money monthly.  Thanks to the internet I get updates on his progress regularly.  Seeing Roger on his way to school in his new uniform, with pencils and notebooks in his knapsack and new pair of shoes felt like the best money I ever spent.

What We Need

After frank conversations with teachers and school directors in both Honduras and Nicaragua, I got the details of what's happening in the classrooms day-to-day.  Here are their top concerns:

  • School safety.   Big priority.  One school director asked for a secure front gate.  Nothing worse than having stray dogs, chickens or even livestock wander into a classroom!
  • Hygiene and sanitation.  They need everything from toothbrushes to garbage cans to educate the children about disease prevention.   It's a top priority when you have no access to water.  In the meantime,  300 malnourished children are sharing a few latrines.  
  • Oh yeah, school stuff would help - pencils, crayons, paper, desks, chairs, rulers and books.  

So why $1,500?

Purchased in bulk, $3 per student could buy 500 students (300 in Nicaragua and another 200 in Honduras) and their teachers the basic tools they need for a successful school year.


The Impact

The cost of being illiterate is incalculable.  Without access to a good education the cycle of poverty will never end.  Who knows where the next great innovation will come from?  The lost potential can never truly be appreciated.  The recent mass exodus to the United States is a direct response to the lack of meaningful opportunity for advancement in Central America. 


Risks & Challenges

The terrible risk we run is that children will not come to school at all.  An attitude of inertia and hopelessness will zap the life out of these children before they've ever had a chance. 

The cycle of poverty continues.  A child who stays home endures a bleak existence.  Faced with zero options for the future and nothing to lose, many parents have sent their children to the United States to look for a better life.  


Other Ways You Can Help

It's not all about money.  Some people just can't contribute financially, but that doesn't mean you can't help.  Don't think your help isn't appreciated!  Here are a few ways you can help us reach our goal:

  • Share this campaign's link on your Facebook page.  Tweet about it.  Blog about it.  Help us expand our network.  Tell all your friends and co-workers to do the same.  We really need folks who can get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Speak to your local church or school group about holding a fundraising event.  There are a ton of fun ways you can raise money!
  • Most of all, wish us luck!

story:
UPDATE ON PHASE 2

Our ad is locked and loaded with Vancouver 24 hrs for Tuesday, October 7th, 2014.

This allowed us to upgrade to a 1/2 page ad for less money than our original 1/3 page ad due to a sale Vancouver 24 hrs is having.

What this means is that any money raised over $954 will go towards purchasing advertising with google that we can target business owners in BC.  

Let's shine the light on the Coalition of BC Businesses folks!

PHASE 2

Thank you, thank you, thank you funders for helping us raise more than $1300 in less than 48 hours to run a two week ad campaign to reach The Tyee's online magazine 100,000 readership!  The ad campaign starts Monday October 29th 2014!   

If 61 funders can raise $1300 in less than 48 hours to help get the message out about the Coalition of BC Businesses then why not aim higher?  Why not a big bold message in a 1/3 page spread in Vancouver 24 hrs' daily magazine to reach its 224,000 readership?  Let's take our campaign to save BC's Public Education System to the streets!!!  

OUR STORY

Hi, I’m Dan Gunn from the Allies for BC Public Education and I want your help to reach BC Business owners to let them know about a hearing in the British Columbia Court of Appeal between the BC Teachers Federation and the Government of BC that they might be involved in.  

The Coalition of BC Businesses, which claims to represent 50,000 employers and 500,000 employees has been granted intervenor status in the hearing.  If a BC Business is a member of the Coalition, their business interests are being represented by the Coalition.  

We are calling for the Coalition to withdraw its intervenor status.  To learn why please visit our website and/or view our video .  We think that the majority of BC businesses who are coalition members are unaware of their involvement in the hearing. We also think they should know so they can decide for themselves if they want to be part of the hearing.  

The hearing is set to start on October 14th, 2014 so we don't have much time! And we need your help to get the message out! 

Phase 1 Details - FUNDED

Our plan is to launch a two week online advertising campaign with The Tyee to let concerned British Columbians know about what is happening so they can reach out to businesses in their communities. 

With a readership of 100,000 The Tyee is a widely read and respected independent online magazine.  The majority of its readership resides in British Columbia and are highly engaged with their communities. These are the people that will help us in our advocacy work by writing letters to the businesses in their communities, and by inspiring their friends, families and community members to take action.  

The hearing is set to start on October 14, 2014 so we don't have much time. This also means that this campaign has the potential to be fast and furious.  Online advertising allows us to change the messaging as we go to reflect this so that we can reach as many of The Tyee's readership as possible.  

What are the specifics?

  • Duration two weeks starting September 29th 2014
  • 2 ads on The Tyee website: One big box ad (300x250) and one Leaderboard ad (728x90)
  • Guaranteed 65,000 impressions (page views) with a possible 100,000 additional impressions
  • Geo targeted to Greater Vancouver and Victoria with visibility to greater British Columbia
  • Tyee graphic designer to assist with creating targeted online ads 


What if we don't reach our goal?
If we do not reach our goal we will make sure that the amount raised is used to purchase the most effective advertising with the amount left over.

story:
In 2009 I left an abusive, long-term relationship; I was allowed to take the furniture I had brought with me 9 years earlier, my car (with its $20,000 loan attached), my clothes, my 16 year old cat, and my disability pension.

I was lost and alone; I had no family and very few friends, and a serious case of depression that saw me fighting the lure of suicide every day.

After scouring the local newspapers, real estate web sites, and local estate agencies I secured reasonably affordable rental housing within a few weeks of being given an ultimatum.

One day not long after I moved in to town, I decided I just couldn’t take anymore and I made a deal with myself. I gave myself 6 months to change the way I felt about life, but it wasn’t just some airy-fairy idea, I came up with a plan.

I had looked at my life and realised in the past I had always caved; I put all my dreams away in little mental compartments to do what other people wanted or expected me to do, other people’s happiness was given higher value by me than my own.

I was miserable, but I decided this was my last chance to rebuild and start again. I knew, as I had from the day I moved out of home at 17, that I was on my own. I had to deal with everything life threw at me without the safety net of a family and this was just another speed bump I was determined to work through.

My dream/ambition had always been to write; I wanted to go to university and learn how but had never had the opportunity, money or family support.

About the same time as this realisation, I started seeing advertisements for Open Universities Australia and applied to study online for a Bachelor of Arts degree with Griffith University, at the ripe old age of 42.

I started as a volunteer with the local Salvation Army chapter at about the same time I applied for university; I worked behind the scenes packing food parcels in their welfare department three mornings per week for the first two years of study and one morning a week for part of my final year. I eventually stopped to focus on my study.

I will be forever grateful for HECS, if I had not been able to defer my fees I would not have been able to study.

I budgeted so strictly that I managed to keep paying off my car loan, paid rent, kept bills up to date, and studied, without any financial help except my disability pension. I never received any monetary help from my ex while we were together and I knew I wouldn't receive anything when we split. I made my choice when I left and though it has made the last 5 years extremely difficult, I guess I can pride myself on doing it by myself.

I was granted my Bachelor of Arts degree in March 2013 after 3years of really hard work and, as an online student, no breaks between semesters.

As soon as I knew I had completed my Bachelor degree I applied and was accepted into the Master of Arts (Writing) program with Swinburne University -  again online through Open Universities Australia.

I started in June 2013 and in November2014 I completed the requirements for that degree. Despite the constant pit of depression and PTSD, I kept going because I realised it was  my last chance to achieve a heartfelt dream.

Now, I need help.

My graduation ceremony is in Melbourne in April. I live in Perth, but on a disability pension and paying off a loan I have no scope to save money and no family to help.

I need to find enough money to cover return airfares for myself (Perth/Melbourne), return airfares for my cousin in Adelaide (the thought of traveling to Melbourne and staying there – alone – is paralysing); I need taxi/petrol money for transfers to and from airports in Perth, Adelaide, and Melbourne, a hotel room in Melbourne for three nights, and taxi to and from the graduation ceremony.

My best estimate, after looking at flight and accommodation costs is I will need approximately $2000

If anyone can help at all, I would be very grateful. If, by some slim chance, people pledge more than I need, the excess will go to paying off some of my car loan which will in turn make my day to day life easier.

I can't think of any better way to celebrate all the hard work of studying (with PTSD and depression) or to reward myself for continuing when all I wanted to do many times was just stop, than to wear that cap and gown in April and cross the stage with other degree recipients.   I still find it hard to believe I have gone from suicidal in 2009 to holding a Master of Arts (Writing) degree in 2014/15 and I can finally say I am proud of myself and how far I have come in 5 years. 

I still have a long way to go; I still deal with depression and PTSD on a daily basis but I know now that I'm not stupid, useless, or pathetic, contrary to what I have been told my entire life.

Thank you for the time you have taken to read my story.

S.

story:
Hey there!  I'm Megan Jo.  And introductions are often an awkward endeavor for me, but I'll give it a shot!


I've loved the piano since I was very young and have been playing it since I was five years old.  I've played a lot of other instruments in my lifetime, too, always tinkering with them and ultimately figuring out how to fix them on my own.  I've always thought, knowing your instrument well enough to fix it makes you a true lover of the instrument and music in general.


A couple of years ago, I was fortunate enough to stumble upon an apprenticeship opportunity with a Registered Piano Technician (RPT) by the name of Bill Shull, of Shull Piano Inc. out of Loma Linda, California.  I loved going to the shop and soaked up all of the knowledge I could.  

The opportunity came about in a rather unconventional way.  I had my piano in storage for a time in Oceanside.  One day, a lady was moving a mattress and bumped a sprinkler head, setting off the entire system.  My piano sat in about 4 inches of water for I don't know how long.  As soon as I found out, I had my piano shipped to a piano technician for repairs.  When my baby grand was all fixed up and ready to come home, I jokingly said to the technician, "It's too bad you don't have an apprenticeship program!  I'd really love to learn the trade!"  To which he replied, "Well, it's funny you should say that.  My apprentices meet here at the shop every Thursday!  Why don't you come down next week?"  And that's when the door of opportunity flung wide open, and my dream career would be realized.

Eventually, travel time and cost made it difficult to meet with Bill and I had to stop attending his classes.  Soon after, I moved north to the Sierras and found myself quite comfortable in a small town, and met a fellow tinkerer of sorts, Ken.  He's been a mentor to me, encouraging me to experiment and offering support and a bit of his knowledge when I need it.  It's been a great relief after moving to a town where I wasn't sure I'd be able to continue my studies and aspirations of becoming a Registered Piano Technician.

Today, I received a brochure in the mail from the Piano Technicians Guild, a world-wide organization of piano technicians.  I've heard of them often and even get a few publications from them in my email.  These people are amazing.  Their knowledge and innovation is astounding!  They're creating their own tools, sharing stories and loving their lives and careers.  

The brochure I got today was for the WESTPAC V (Western and Pacific Regional Piano Technician's Guild Conference), held annually.  Honestly, I'm not sure how they got my mailing address, but I'm so glad they did!  Looking through this thing, I'm amazed at the number of classes, instructors, exhibits, and concerts.  I got so excited looking through it!  Imagine, Megan Jo, how much you could learn in these four days!  On the back page of this little booklet are the fees.  My excitement settled, and so did I.  But then I had this idea...  maybe the public would want to help send me to learn more of this trade.  Maybe they'd want to help me keep my dream alive and thriving.


Here are the fees, broken down:
Registration for a non-PTG member, (that's me); $399, 
           --includes four full days of classes, exhibits, discussions and hands on learning!
A special class that I want to take for voicing is; $95
A room at the cheapest hotel in Ontario, CA; $49/night.  4 nights; 196+tx


I haven't figured in gas or food.  If I'm only $100 short, I'll go but not take the special class.  If I don't raise enough to go at all, the money will be held for next year's conference.

A little bit about Piano Technology and what they'll be teaching at the conference;
Tuning a piano isn't as easy as you might think.  Sure, some, maybe even most, technicians use an electronic tuning device.   However, to pass the exam and gain the title of Registered Piano Technician (RPT), you have to tune a piano perfectly by ear using only one tuning fork.  I'm sure you can imagine how difficult that might be!  It's not just about getting the frequencies to stop fighting (as with a guitar), it's about getting them to fight just the right amount.  At the conference, they'll be teaching specific methods to help make it a little easier.  I'm really looking forward to that!

Voicing a piano has to do with manipulating the tone that is produced when the hammers hit the strings.  If the hammers are too hard, the tone is bright and may even hurt the ears.  If the tone is too dull, it's difficult, if not impossible, for a pianist to get the right expression out of the instrument.  When the tone is to bright, a tool is used with a series of sharp needles on it, and those needles are pressed into the hammer head felt to help soften the fibers and thus softening the tone.  If the hammers are too soft, several methods could be applied.   Most commonly, a solution of lacquer is put on the hammers and allowed to dry, stiffening the fibers and therefore brightening the tone.  

Regulating a piano involves all sorts of tiny measurements.  When a piano is regulated, the feel of the keys is what's really being worked on.  Every component in the action (the parts that make the piano play) is designed to work at exactly the right time and with exactly the right force and exactly the right amount of movement.  If something is off, the whole thing is off.  This is a part of piano tech that I don't have any experience with and am most excited to dive right in to.  

Repairing a piano encompasses SO much, there isn't any way I could possibly try to fit it all in here.  There are so many moving parts in a piano, all of them susceptible to damage from the changes in weather.  Felts get warn out, things stop moving, things break...  You get the idea.  Repairing pianos is a lifelong pursuit and I am looking forward to the journey!

Rebuilding a piano is something I got a little taste of while working with Bill Shull.  There is some amazing feeling you get when something is just a shell of itself and you're the one slowly putting it back together and making it sing like it ought to!  What a fascinating experience!

The conference also offers smaller classes like specific repairs on small piano parts and also one for building your own tools.

If you can help send me to this four day incubator of dreams, I'd be so very grateful.  There isn't much I can do in return for you, except send a thank you card.  Or, if you're in my area and have a piano, Free Tuning for you!  I'm just so excited at the thought of going to this conference.  I can't imagine how I'll feel when it's really happening!  


If you aren't able to donate, it's not a problem.  If you could just take a minute to share this with friends and family, that'd be wonderful!  Thanks for reading and considering and contributing!

A couple of years ago, I was fortunate enough to stumble upon an apprenticeship opportunity with a Registered Piano Technician (RPT) by the name of Bill Shull, of Shull Piano Inc. out of Loma Linda, California.  I loved going to the shop and soaked up all of the knowledge I could.  

The opportunity came about in a rather unconventional way.  I had my piano in storage for a time in Oceanside.  One day, a lady was moving a mattress and bumped a sprinkler head, setting off the entire system.  My piano sat in about 4 inches of water for I don't know how long.  As soon as I found out, I had my piano shipped to a piano technician for repairs.  When my baby grand was all fixed up and ready to come home, I jokingly said to the technician, "It's too bad you don't have an apprenticeship program!  I'd really love to learn the trade!"  To which he replied, "Well, it's funny you should say that.  My apprentices meet here at the shop every Thursday!  Why don't you come down next week?"  And that's when the door of opportunity flung wide open, and my dream career would be realized.

Eventually, travel time and cost made it difficult to meet with Bill and I had to stop attending his classes.  Soon after, I moved north to the Sierras and found myself quite comfortable in a small town, and met a fellow tinkerer of sorts, Ken.  He's been a mentor to me, encouraging me to experiment and offering support and a bit of his knowledge when I need it.  It's been a great relief after moving to a town where I wasn't sure I'd be able to continue my studies and aspirations of becoming a Registered Piano Technician.

Today, I received a brochure in the mail from the Piano Technicians Guild, a world-wide organization of piano technicians.  I've heard of them often and even get a few publications from them in my email.  These people are amazing.  Their knowledge and innovation is astounding!  They're creating their own tools, sharing stories and loving their lives and careers.  

The brochure I got today was for the WESTPAC V (Western and Pacific Regional Piano Technician's Guild Conference), held annually.  Honestly, I'm not sure how they got my mailing address, but I'm so glad they did!  Looking through this thing, I'm amazed at the number of classes, instructors, exhibits, and concerts.  I got so excited looking through it!  Imagine, Megan Jo, how much you could learn in these four days!  On the back page of this little booklet are the fees.  My excitement settled, and so did I.  But then I had this idea...  maybe the public would want to help send me to learn more of this trade.  Maybe they'd want to help me keep my dream alive and thriving.



Here are the fees, broken down:
Registration for a non-PTG member, (that's me); $399, 
           --includes four full days of classes, exhibits, discussions and hands on learning!
A special class that I want to take for voicing is; $95

A room at the cheapest hotel in Ontario, CA; $49/night.  4 nights; 196+tx



I haven't figured in gas or food.  If I'm only $100 short, I'll go but not take the special class.  If I don't raise enough to go at all, the money will be held for next year's conference.

A little bit about Piano Technology and what they'll be teaching at the conference;

Tuning a piano isn't as easy as you might think.  Sure, some, maybe even most, technicians use an electronic tuning device.   However, to pass the exam and gain the title of Registered Piano Technician (RPT), you have to tune a piano perfectly by ear using only one tuning fork.  I'm sure you can imagine how difficult that might be!  It's not just about getting the frequencies to stop fighting (as with a guitar), it's about getting them to fight just the right amount.  At the conference, they'll be teaching specific methods to help make it a little easier.  I'm really looking forward to that!


Voicing a piano has to do with manipulating the tone that is produced when the hammers hit the strings.  If the hammers are too hard, the tone is bright and may even hurt the ears.  If the tone is too dull, it's difficult, if not impossible, for a pianist to get the right expression out of the instrument.  When the tone is to bright, a tool is used with a series of sharp needles on it, and those needles are pressed into the hammer head felt to help soften the fibers and thus softening the tone.  If the hammers are too soft, several methods could be applied.   Most commonly, a solution of lacquer is put on the hammers and allowed to dry, stiffening the fibers and therefore brightening the tone.  


Regulating a piano involves all sorts of tiny measurements.  When a piano is regulated, the feel of the keys is what's really being worked on.  Every component in the action (the parts that make the piano play) is designed to work at exactly the right time and with exactly the right force and exactly the right amount of movement.  If something is off, the whole thing is off.  This is a part of piano tech that I don't have any experience with and am most excited to dive right in to.  


Repairing a piano encompasses SO much, there isn't any way I could possibly try to fit it all in here.  There are so many moving parts in a piano, all of them susceptible to damage from the changes in weather.  Felts get warn out, things stop moving, things break...  You get the idea.  Repairing pianos is a lifelong pursuit and I am looking forward to the journey!


Rebuilding a piano is something I got a little taste of while working with Bill Shull.  There is some amazing feeling you get when something is just a shell of itself and you're the one slowly putting it back together and making it sing like it ought to!  What a fascinating experience!

The conference also offers smaller classes like specific repairs on small piano parts and also one for building your own tools.

If you can help send me to this four day incubator of dreams, I'd be so very grateful.  There isn't much I can do in return for you, except send a thank you card.  Or, if you're in my area and have a piano, Free Tuning for you!  I'm just so excited at the thought of going to this conference.  I can't imagine how I'll feel when it's really happening!  

If you aren't able to donate, it's not a problem.  If you could just take a minute to share this with friends and family, that'd be wonderful!  Thanks for reading and considering and contributing!

story:
Mr. Rolf Gunnar

Hello to all Conifer High School alumni or current students, my name is Thomas Kim. I graduated from our little school May 2013, and currently study architecture at Syracuse University. I wanted to pitch this crazy idea to you guys, but first let me explain why. The man, the legend, Mr Gunnar has touched our lives in one way or another. He was there for us when you needed help not only in school, but for personal reasons and anything beyond that spectrum. Mr. Gunnar is one of the most devoted teachers I have ever crossed paths with, and that path will not be easy to cross once again. 
I remember my junior year in high school, we were all assigned our personal narratives. After being touched by many of the stories I heard from the seniors, I decided to release my own story - something I had kept within myself and family for a while. It was a story about my mother, whom passed away from ovarian/breast cancer in the winter of 2008, on December 20th. As a 13 year old, I could not accept reality and the future that was dawning upon me. It seemed to all be a blur, and things seemed to be moving so fast until it all came to a sudden halt when Mr. Gunnar approached me about writing about my mother. 
It was not until then when I realized that I hadn't really tried to reminisce, to hide the pain, and I never really attempted to think about it all until he prompted me to. Through many tears and sorrow, I finally had built up the courage to write a paper about my mother. And ever since, I had my mind cleared, and my goals set. It was an enlightening moment for me, to discover myself through self analysis and literature. All made possible by our beloved Mr. Gunnar.
If you guys have not heard yet, Mr. Gunnar will be retiring as an English teacher at our old high school, and will be stepping down officially on September 30th. I think that out of a lot of people in our lives, this man deserves something spectacular after all he has done for us. It's time we bucked our heads together and make something great happen for someone we greatly appreciate in our lives.

What We Need

I began talking to Mr. Gunnar about what he would like to do after retirement, and since I'm a super spy, I sensed that he has NO idea what I'm doing with the information he gave me. I asked him, "Mr. Gunnar, if you could go anywhere on Earth, where would it be and why? I was just wondering because I always wondered why people do what they do after retirement (do people really wonder that though?)" To which he replied, "I'd love to go to the Far East. I've never been there before, and I think it would be mesmerizing." 

  • Ever since his reply, I have researched for a couple hours and found that the average price of a trip to send Mr. Gunnar to Delhi, India with a fully guided tour + flight will run us about 1500-2000 dollars. Crazy, I know. 
  • I really apologize, my hands are full these days and I really can't come up with many perks to offer you guys. You will receive my genuine thanks and ever lasting love of course, and the least I can do is offer you a free photoshoot with an unlimited number of people, in a location of your own choosing (keep in mind that I return to Syracuse August 19th). 
  • If our wallets cannot conquer this big price tag, then all funds will go to Mr. Gunnar, in hopes that his savings account can suffice for the rest. Its the thought that counts right? 

The Truth

Every single day we spend money on stupid little things like skittles (which are actually not that dumb, especially if you get the tropical kind), fast food (just make a PB&J if you have to, its way cheaper) and little knick knacks, y'all know what I'm talking about. 

All I'm asking you to do is to direct 15-30 dollars of the money you would be spending on fart pillows or plastic spoons, towards the cause of sending this awesome dude halfway across the world. 

    2000 DOLLARS?! You're f*****g crazy!

    Yeah, I know. I like living in the fast lane. But its just because I don't want to send him on a trip into a foreign country where he'll be guided by the local kartel whom might lure him into their drug ops and before we know it we have a world conflict between the US and India (whom I really haven't heard much from in the news... but then again I don't watch the news). 

    I'll admit. I've never done this before. I just know from growing up in Conifer that our community bond is one of the strongest I'll ever experience. I'm not sure if we're gonna hit that 2K but I sure as hell believe that if we all work together, it can be done. Neil walked on the moon, so why can't we raise two thousand dollars?

    Other Ways You Can Help Without $$$$$

    15 dollars though... Really? But really, I understand. I'm a broke college kid just like you are. I'm just in a spot right now where the money I'll be putting in here is just the difference between a few meals and some architecture supplies, which I can salvage and starve for. But if you SERIOUSLY can't put in any money to this cause, I completely understand, no hard feelings. Heres what you can do instead;

    • Like I said, Conifer has a pretty big heart. If we get the community involved with this, 2K is gonna be a reality in no time. Help us get the word out! But make sure to do it quietly enough so that it doesn't reach Mr. Gunnar's ears! And if it does, tell him he's crazy for thinking that people are raising two thousand dollars for him to travel to India. Crazy. Just craaaaaaazy. 
    • Word of mouth, texting, PHONE CALLS (something we need to bring back these days for Christ's sake), e-mails(?), snail mail, pony express, pigeon, telepathy, post card. Anything. It's gonna help. 

    Lets do this together guys. Giving back is the greatest joy there is, ain't it?

story:
Non-Negotiable Sites of Struggle

The second MLA Subconference in Vancouver will center on struggle as a non-negotiable and constitutive action for responding to ours and others’ increasing contingency.When we say non-negotiable, we mean that the following tactics are no longer optional: Direct and collective action, critical research on the financial and labor structures of higher education, union organizing, collectivizing wages and resources, making knowledge and information networks available by whatever means possible, and rejecting gains for some workers that would mean losses for others. These tactics can no longer be considered nostalgically as actions that belong to the past nor idealistically as something to do in the future. They are necessary tactics we need now as we grapple with higher education as a site of economic accumulation and subjective disciplining. For more details, please visit our website.

Solidarity

We'll be sharing and discussing the above tactics in trainings and panels this January, but we need your help in getting the Subcon organizing committee and presenters (primarily grad students, non-grad adjuncts, and social-justice organizers) there. We've received $3,000 in institutional contributions so far, but with airfare running between $300-$600 from most points in the U.S. and Canada—and with 12 members of the organizing committee, and as many as 20 presenters, all coming specifically for the Subcon—we need your support. Help us expand the Subcon network and accelerate the transformation of higher ed.

Your contribution will go toward:

  • Roundtrip fares for plane, train, and bus travel.
  • Mileage reimbursement for those driving.
  • A limited number of hotel rooms (we plan to provide home-stays for most participants).
  • Inter-Vancouver public transportation.

Change

The first Subconference reversed the power structure of the academy, centering grad students, adjuncts, and community organizers and their experience and knowledge and generating impactful information, copious media attention, and much ongoing discussion. More than 60 people joined us, and we expect to have even more this time. Your support will help us continue to make change.

    Other Ways to Support the Subcon

    Have frequent flier miles to donate? A hotel room for MLA that will be covered by your department that you'd like to share? Another idea? Let us know! Email MLASubconference@gmail.com.

story:
Hello! My name is Luis Garces, I live in México City, I am 19 years old and just graduated from high school.

I have always had a desire to travel and learn from other cultures. My goal is to increase my perspective and ideologies on life and the world before studding at college.

For that reason my plan before starting college next January 2015 will be traveling to Thailand, India and Cambodia with a group of 18 students and 3 program leaders during 18 weeks.

I was accepted in a program called Thinking Beyond Border. We are going to be studying alimentation and education in those countries and at the end of the three months we will make a project and meet representatives in Washington from the World Bank, Congress, and NGOs to raise awareness about education and alimentation.

What I want to achieve during this three months is to learn from critical global issues and from different needs people have in different countries.

In Thailand I will be living with a host family and do fieldwork with locals to investigate how farmers, government, and businesses cooperate to balance demand for food with the ecosystem in Northern Thailand.

In India I will explore how education can empower individuals and communities to improve health and create equity and justice, and work in education centers for women and children in some of the poorest parts of Jaipur.

And in Cambodia as part of the program I will be exploring Angkor Wat and Phnom Penh.

With this program I will have the opportunity to help other, improve my self and learn different points of view and living, and most importantly, the experience will provide me with insight that was once inconceivable.

This journey will supply me with culture awareness, maturity, a more globalized perspective on issues, and have an impact on the lives of others as I realize the part I play in this world.

I would greatly appreciate contribution from you.

Fundraising:

Total Tuition (including estimated airfare): $14,250

Thinking Beyond Borders will match the donations I receive up to $3,000!

My goal is to raise more than $3,000, and all funds will go directly to my tuition. Even if this goal is not reached the flexible fundraising option still allows the money to go towards my trip and will still be matched by Thinking Beyond Borders.

Anything you are willing to contribute is appreciated! Even if you don’t have money to donate, spreading the word through social media and other forms of communication to people who may be interested about my campaign is helpful.

Giving back:

I will share with you the experiences I have while on this journey in order to give value to your investment. I will offer various tokens of my appreciation to different amounts of donations.

Perks:

Subscribe to my Blog! - $25

A special mention to you in my blog! - $ 50

A copy of each of the multimedia projects I produce! - $ 100

Personal Postcards from each country I visit! - $250

A dinner I make using a recipe learned abroad! - $ 500

The Impact

What I will learn from participating in this program will have an impact on my future and a positive impact on the lives of others as I realize the role I play in this world.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don’t have money to donate spreading the word through social media to people who may be interested about my campaign is helpful. Thank you for your support!

story:
Kitenge Africa Foundation was established in 2008 to feed, clothe and educate vulnerable street children, 5,000 of whom live rough on the streets of Kampala, Uganda's capital.  In February 2013, Kitenge Africa was able to support 20 children to continue their education at Busomba school in Mpigi district.

However we currently have a $2,600 gap in funds which means the children, now 30 in number, may be unable to go back to school in September.  Please help us to help these children continue their education and to provide them with much needed food and medical care.

Your donation can have a major impact on these children's lives.  In order to get them back to school the following funds are needed:

Food $540
Basic necessities $205
Health care and sanitation $200
Primary school fees $287
Secondary school fees $240
School supplies $210
Operating costs $100
Previous debts for food, fees, staff salaries, health care $700

Education has the power to transform lives, to help these children stay safe, grow to be able support themselves and others in their communities.  The children aspire to become teachers and doctors, so that they in turn can give back to others. Please consider making a gift to help these children toward a better future.  Kitenge Africa is truly grateful for your support

If you aren't in a position to donate you can still help us by spreading the word! Please share our campaign on Facebook and encourage your friends to support the work of Kitenge Africa Foundation!
