story:
Short Summary

Tim Shew is an accomplished television, film, and stage actor. His most famous role was that of Jean Valjean in the smash Broadway hit Les Miserables (later played by Hugh Jackman in the movie adaptation), a role which he has played all over the world. In order to provide a compelling and relevant performance opportunity for the choral students at Lawrence North High School, we have invited Mr. Shew to perform with us in October. Mr. Shew is excited to join with us, and we are thrilled to have him with us. As you can imagine, though, to bring in a professional actor to work with students carries with it some hefty costs.

What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is intended to help us fund Mr. Shew's appearance fee as well as airfare, rental car, hotel accommodations, and production costs for our performance. Every little bit helps, and, ideally, we want to provide this opportunity to our students without negatively impacting our finances for the activities that we normally do throughout the rest of the school year. With a competitive show choir program as well as large in-house performances, our budget is already tight. We believe the opportunity to perform with and learn from Mr. Shew is worth the expense, but we launch this campaign to eliminate the financial impact this event could have on the rest of the school year.

As a contributor, we have several perks available to you, including tickets to the performance, LN Choir apparel, autographed photos of Mr. Shew, and more. Take a look at our suggested contribution levels for more details.

    The Impact

    Working with Mr. Shew will be a tremendous opportunity for the choral students at Lawrence North. It will give them the chance to see, first-hand, what it takes to be successful as a professional performer (or in any other professional field, for that matter) and is a rare opportunity to perform with one of Broadway's best. We want to go beyond the typical high school experience and do something special that our students will remember forever.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Any contribution helps the cause and is greatly appreciated. However, if you are unable to make a donation at this time, please help by spreading the word about this event and this campaign. And, donor or not, we'd love to see you for the performance on October 3rd!
story_txt:
Short Summary
Tim Shew is an accomplished television, film, and stage actor. His most famous role was that of Jean Valjean in the smash Broadway hit Les Miserables (later played by Hugh Jackman in the movie adaptation), a role which he has played all over the world. In order to provide a compelling and relevant performance opportunity for the choral students at Lawrence North High School, we have invited Mr. Shew to perform with us in October. Mr. Shew is excited to join with us, and we are thrilled to have him with us. As you can imagine, though, to bring in a professional actor to work with students carries with it some hefty costs.   What We Need & What You Get This campaign is intended to help us fund Mr. Shew's appearance fee as well as airfare, rental car, hotel accommodations, and production costs for our performance. Every little bit helps, and, ideally, we want to provide this opportunity to our students without negatively impacting our finances for the activities that we normally do throughout the rest of the school year. With a competitive show choir program as well as large in-house performances, our budget is already tight. We believe the opportunity to perform with and learn from Mr. Shew is worth the expense, but we launch this campaign to eliminate the financial impact this event could have on the rest of the school year.
As a contributor, we have several perks available to you, including tickets to the performance, LN Choir apparel, autographed photos of Mr. Shew, and more. Take a look at our suggested contribution levels for more details.

  The Impact Working with Mr. Shew will be a tremendous opportunity for the choral students at Lawrence North. It will give them the chance to see, first-hand, what it takes to be successful as a professional performer (or in any other professional field, for that matter) and is a rare opportunity to perform with one of Broadway's best. We want to go beyond the typical high school experience and do something special that our students will remember forever.

  
Other Ways You Can Help

 Any contribution helps the cause and is greatly appreciated. However, if you are unable to make a donation at this time, please help by spreading the word about this event and this campaign. And, donor or not, we'd love to see you for the performance on October 3rd!

story:
Over 2,500 Yale alumni have signed an open letter to the Yale President and Yale Corporation calling for diversity in naming the two new residential colleges. The letter calls for the University to name the two new colleges after alumni of color, alumnae, LGBT alumni, and other alumni not currently reflected in the namesakes of our residential colleges. The letter has been drawing lots of attention within the Yale community, largely through social media. Ultimately, the Yale Daily News declined to publish the letter itself, due to the massive attention the letter has already received. Instead, YDN published an article about alumni's incredible showing of support for the effort (http://bit.ly/10Wu0SD).

Help us keep the momentum going! We want to publish a full-page advertisement in the Yale Daily News that would list all of the alumni signatories who support diversity in naming Yale's new colleges. We are also working with web designers who will develop a website showcasing all of the wonderful alumni that deserve a college named after them, such as Edward Bouchet 1874 GRD 1876, Grace Hopper GRD ’34, Yung Wing 1854, Henry Roe Cloud '10, and Pauli Murray JSD '65. We hope to include a link to the website in the advertisement.

With over 2,500 signatories, it won't take much from each of us to make this happen. (If we each gave $1, we would have enough to publish two full-page advertisements.) Any money collected above our campaign goal will go toward promoting this cause among Yale alumni, faculty, students, and administration. Please donate whatever you can today!

story:
Introduction

Dharma Civilization Foundation (DCF) is a California based 501(c)3 Non-Profit Community-based Organization. It seeks to promote and enhance establishment of the systematic study of "Dharma," its interpretation and application in modern contexts. Establishing "Applied Dharma" for today's world requires a strong university presence.

In the first phase at USC, DCF established a visiting professor in Hindu Studies, which is running successfully since the last two years and has been a phenomenal success.

In its second phase at USC, DCF is establishing the Swami Vivekananda Endowed Chair in Hindu Dharma Studies and seeks its funding through community efforts. This endowment will be the foundation of the future Swami Vivekananda Center for Indic Civilization and Dharma Studies.

JOIN US IN THIS HISTORIC HERITAGE COMMUNITY INITIATIVE.

This initiative at USC is of critical importance in today's context where Dharma does not have its own voice in American Academia. It aims to achieve the following:

  • To promote the understanding of India's Civilization, Religion, and Culture through Education.
  • Create a community of Scholar-Practitioners.
  • Representation of Dharma in American Academia, where its current representation is negligible.
  • To "promote a concord of civilizations rather than the clash of civilizations."
  • To preserve the beautiful messages of the Gita, Upanishads, Yoga, & Vedanta etc.
This effort will shape the future of Dharma Education in North America.

What We Need & What You Get

The chair at USC requires $3.3 Million. So far the pledged & collected funds are above $700,000, which is 25% of the total requirement.  Another 25% is being collected from Southern California, and the next 25% is being raised through various events & donors through out USA. The remaining 25% or more is being raised through the crowd-funding community: THAT'S YOU!

All donors will be recognized on the Website as Dharma Donors.

The biggest reward for the dharma-donor is that you will become a Dharmapala (Dharma Hero), preserving and protecting Dharma for future generations.

Join us in this effort to establish Dharma in the Temples of Knowledge, so that the ideal of "One Consciousness, One Humanity, One Destiny" does not disappear from the earth. 

The Impact

  • The Swami Vivekananda Chair at USC will be in the School of Religion which is about to open the first Ph.D. Program in Asian Religions in Southern California.
  • This is an important milestone because there are currently no other Ph.D.  programs in the religions of Asia that serves the approx. 18 M people of SoCal. 
  •  The Swami Vivekananda Chair would make it possible to offer a PhD focus on the Dharma Traditions of India and Hindu Dharma in particular. 
  • Your contribution will ensure  the inclusion of Dharma in the first Ph.D. program in Religious Studies (beyond the Abrahamic religions) amongst the major universities of Southern California. 
  • This will develop multi-deciplinary programs in Indic Civilization & Dharma Studies such as: 
  1.        GE (required General Education) courses
  2.        Certificate Programs
  3.        Minor & Major Undergraduate programs
  4.        Concentrations in graduate degree programs
  5.        Research applications of Dharma principals such as: integration, pluralism, sustainability, and contemplative studies.  

Challenges

How do we ensure that the University will honor the “intent” and “spirit” of the donor?

The intention and purpose of the donor is clearly documented and stipulated in the gift agreement. This is a legal document, and is binding on the University. The Agreement also ensures that University’s Faculty search process recruits a Professor who is eminently suited to fulfill the intention of the donor.  The DCF and heritage community will be in ongoing engagement with the designated faculty and administration so as to ensure that the donor’s intent is preserved across key transitions. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word about DCF's work & campaign to fund Swami Vivekananda Chair at USC.

Please email at info@dcfusa.org for further information or call at +1-310-343-9471.

Media coverage about historic chair at USC:

story:
#30Days of ThanksgivingLO 

You may not know this about us, but we both had the AMAZING opportunity to go through a program called Legal Outreach in high school. Legal Outreach works with students from underserved neighborhoods around NYC and prepares them to succeed in high school, college, and beyond.  

As part of an alumni fundraising initiative, we're fundraising this November to make it possible for more students like us to go through Legal Outreach.  

Our Story : Lorena and Marlene 

We are Marlene Cedeno and Lorena Rodriguez! Marlene grew up in the Bronx and attended the High School of American Studies at Lehman College and Lorena is a Harlem native and attended Frederick Douglass Academy. We are both alums of NYC's public school system and of Legal Outreach, a 4-year college-preparatory program to which we credit much of our academic success. Coincidentally, we both also ended up at Amherst College and graduated in 2013.

      

         Lorena                                                     Marlene 

Because of Legal Outreach, we navigated our high school years and the college admissions process much more smoothly and successfully than we otherwise would have. We would like to make it possible for as many other students as possible to have the same enriching and life-changing opportunity and YOU can help us pay it forward.  

Your support can change the lives of more students like us!

Your Support Will... 

Make it possible for more students like us to go through Legal Outreach for four years of free programming, including a debate program, SAT prep, writing classes, mentoring, college application workshops, and much more! 

Of the students LO supports: 

  • 100% graduated HS on time (only 66% of NYC public school students do) 
  • 99% went on to colleges and universities 

Other Ways You Can Help 

  • Donate to our campaign before December 2nd, 2014 
  • Share our campaign on social media 
  • Encourage your networks to support our campaign 

We're thankful for LO and we're thankful for your support!  

#30DaysofThanksgivingLO
www.legaloutreach.org
www.facebook.com/legaloutreach
@legaloutreach

story:
Traveling Yoginista

Hello contributors, my name is Desiree Crossman and I go by Traveling Yoginista. I've spent the last decade traveling abroad, broke as a joke, or as a smart saver, it really depends on the situation. When I younger, I knew I wanted to explore the globe, I felt this innate connection with the exploration of what mother earth has to offer. I spent my years in the twenties living it up, not exactly sure of the path I was taking, until I came into an intense relationship that changed my life. 

This relationship helped me in so many ways and even during the darkest, and difficult moments, I somehow turned to yoga. I had no idea what I was doing and I don't know why I fell into it. However 3 years later, during this pivotal year of re-examining myself and who I am, I understood it was what was needed to be who I am now. 

In a short story version, I went to school for six months training for the certification back in 2011. I received the certification in Dec 2011, I had so much information going on in my head,  at the same time I was looking to explore southeast Asia on my own to see what other teachers had to offer. I was complacent in San Diego, I felt there was more. In 2012 I saved enough money to travel to Thailand, Cambodia, Vietnam, and Bali (www.travelingyoginista.com). It was a profound experience and I gained a lot of insight. I was single at the time but was missing my ex and so after I returned to the states, we rekindled. It didn't last long.

All of 2013 I decided to move to the Philippines to practice with an Indian who was born into yoga by family and I spent six months training with him and his beautiful wife. I lived in their home, slept on the mat on the floor, took cold showers, walked everywhere, lived off peanuts. It was intense. I also rekindled again with my significant other understanding forgiveness, acceptance, compassion, compromise, and being present. I loved and love to love. I gave all I could give, but when the energy is not connecting, what do you do? I was unknowingly, suppressing my emotions. I went into robotic mode just plugging away to yoga and trying to keep an emotional draining relationship alive by trying to be perfect for someone and holding onto what seemed to hold on to me, yoga. 

Towards the end of 2013, there was something that developing in me that I felt but was again, suppressing. The intuition was becoming heightened and I felt like I was drowning, I wasn't myself. We went back to the states, and something told me I needed to cut ties. It came over me, and I was a hostage. I left my ex and I didn't look back. I couldn't, that force took over and I was battling my heart versus my head for months. I went through ups and downs and it enabled me to keep focus of what I didn't loose, yoga. This year was the biggest learning experience I could of gone through and I began to understand things with clarity though I was going through sadness. Yoga was my THERAPY. 

 This year I took more training, I learned human design (3/5 profile), I delve into managing a yoga studio, I taught as much as I could, I worked three jobs to make up for the mistakes I made last year, and I sacrificed what I thought was going to be forever, I had to. I knew who I was, and it seemed everything else was pushing me to live it. I saw 11:11 everywhere and so, my spirit was being reborn. The force kept me moving forward no matter how many times I was on the verge of breaking, I was transitioning into the person I was meant to be and I still am. 

Readers, I LOVE teaching! I love teaching yoga, I love learning. I'm blind in my left eye and I am naturally an introvert. Yoga has helped me overcome so much fear within myself and to be able to share what I learn onto others is substantial to my growth as a person. Writing this is coming from the heart and soul. This year I went from having no money, not sure where I was going to teach, thankfully living free with people to save money, to now taking more training workshops, putting together events, managing a studio, working on weekends, and saving. I live in a tiny little studio (thanks to learning how to live sufficiently and thrifty) with no tv, no couch, just a couple of thai mats to sleep on, a portable hot plate cooker, and a yoga mat. Yes, I live about as simple as you can imagine. I didn't even have internet for nearly 5 months. Luckily I had a car still. 

Going to India has been a goal of mine for years, I said I was going to go, and I am. I initially booked a one way this year to Rishikesh to take my course in October but the intuition told me to wait until the beginning of next year, for a couple reasons. 1) I needed to save more money and 2) The intuition told me opportunities would present themselves and I needed to stay longer. I honored that intuition. 

The contributions from this campaign will allow me to travel comfortably for 5 months. I booked a one way ticket to Delhi, put aside money for training which is $1630 for six weeks intensive. After the training, I intend to either go to Nepal on a backpacking adventure (I've never backpacked believe it or not despite traveling around the globe), travel to Thailand to retake my Thai massage course in Chiang Mai and then travel back to the Philippines for a month. I love taking photos as well and who's to say I won't work while I'm away, an opportunity may present itself along the way.I would like to volunteer my time somewhere when I'm abroad as well. I looked into getting the TESL certification and the program I contacted was to send me to Myanmar but it was $3,000 for the training. I just want to feel safe regardless. This is a six month adventure, tentatively and I have some money saved, but nearly enough. This is why I choose to give Indiegogo a try. 

At my age, though I'm in my 30's I accepted I am a non conformist, and I'm ok with it. I learned I'm an INTJ on the MBTI, which allowed me to accept what I knew all along, I like to think and master what I set out to do, I want to master my craft of travel and yoga, to be able to share and teach what I learned, even the mistakes. I am me, and I hope you enjoy reading of the substance within me. 

* Indian Visa/Nepalese

* Malaria shot

* Trains, planes, automobiles, boats - transportation

* Allowing myself to volunteer

* Any additional training I find a long the way

 I will be a 500 hour Experienced Registered Yoga Teacher (ERYT) and I can start to train other teachers on a path like mine. 

If I don't reach my goal of $3,000 it will go towards my return. I'll have financial stability ready for me when I return back to the states. You can also follow my journey on my website www.travelingyoginista.com. 


This is why your dollar matters!

Some of my family say I'm running away, but really I'm actually going home and returning home. The dollar[s] you contribute, if you had the opportunity to do it, would you? There's nothing else I can describe other then I have been through trials and tribulations of life, I've made mistakes, I've traveled, I've lived, and want to keep living. Your dollar matters because it will help support a soul living in this world doing what it was meant to do. There will be ups and downs, trials and tribulations, I'm introverted, I like to go off the radar for awhile to reset my mind. I don't like doing the social media thing, I don't but in this day in age, I've learned to accept it. I choose the name Traveling Yoginista for a reason, I love to travel, I love to share what I learned, I observe, I learn, I am a yogi. There are fashionistas, baristas, senoritas, but not many yoginistas. Be a yoginista, be you and stand for you. I say I a lot, because I am my own experiment and experience. 

Other Ways You Can Help 

If you know of anyone or anything that you feel would contribute to this travel campaign, other sponsors, websites, etc.... Please feel free to connect me. Thank you for reading, I hope you find this campaign genuine. 

Thank you, love and light.

Desiree

  If I don't reach my goal of $3,000 it will go towards my return. I'll have financial stability ready for me when I return back to the states. You can also follow my journey on my website www.travelingyoginista.com.    
    This is why your dollar matters! Some of my family say I'm running away, but really I'm actually going home and returning home. The dollar[s] you contribute, if you had the opportunity to do it, would you? There's nothing else I can describe other then I have been through trials and tribulations of life, I've made mistakes, I've traveled, I've lived, and want to keep living. Your dollar matters because it will help support a soul living in this world doing what it was meant to do. There will be ups and downs, trials and tribulations, I'm introverted, I like to go off the radar for awhile to reset my mind. I don't like doing the social media thing, I don't but in this day in age, I've learned to accept it. I choose the name Traveling Yoginista for a reason, I love to travel, I love to share what I learned, I observe, I learn, I am a yogi. There are fashionistas, baristas, senoritas, but not many yoginistas. Be a yoginista, be you and stand for you. I say I a lot, because I am my own experiment and experience. 
Other Ways You Can Help 
If you know of anyone or anything that you feel would contribute to this travel campaign, other sponsors, websites, etc.... Please feel free to connect me. Thank you for reading, I hope you find this campaign genuine. 
Thank you, love and light.

Desiree

story:
What Is Hume Hawaii?

Hume Hawaii is a camp for Hawaiian youth grades 7-12 that blends together an epic camp experience with one of the most beautiful locations in the world. Rock solid teaching and worship, high-energy recreation, food, free-time and friends create memories that last and will leave an impression that won't fade.

What Noelle Needs

I need to raise $500.  The $408 of that goes to the expense of the Youth Camp and the rest goes to miscellaneous expenses including the fee here on Indiegogo and a little bit of pocket money.

What You Get

A Thank You, A Car Wash and A Promo

... and the sweet feeling of knowing that you have help me fulfill my wish of attending Hume Hawaii

 

TAKE NOTE: The CAR WASH TICKET PRICE is $5 each.  In the donation box it is a perk for the $10 donation with my thank you note. The car wash is on FEBRUARY 2, 8AM to 1 PM at HOPE CHAPEL.  If you just want to buy a $5 ticket from me at the car wash itself, that is goo too. :)

 

NOTE: My mom helped me set-up this page. Thanks Mom :)

story:
I am writing to ask for the opportunity to submit our project, outlined below and in our Proposal for Funding, for support by you or your organization. This is a most unusual and innovative undertaking, involving young men from at-risk neighborhoods in an educational enterprise to build their confidence, leadership skills, community involvement and educational progress.

 

Ukwaluka: South Africa 2013 Project, in its maiden year, plans to take 10 African-American, African, Caribbean, and Latino students in their senior year of high school to South Africa for approximately two weeks, to engage them in educational, community-based activities and give them in-depth exposure to South African culture, diversity and institutions. The purpose of this, as outlined in the Proposal, is to uplift and empower these young men, in the absence of appropriate male role models, and help them to develop the inner resources to advance their education and become socially responsible leaders.  The following are objectives for this project, addressed in great detail in the proposal:

  • Create equity among students. 
  • Improve college readiness and employment marketability. 
  • Mentor students in becoming global citizens who contribute to all communities. 
  • Enhance school culture and build incentives for current and prospective students. 
  • Establish partnerships with South African organizations such as Afrika Tikkum and Robben Island for ongoing program/opportunity. 

 

Included in this curriculum is a three-day public service project in the townships, an overnight stay and private tour of Robben Island prison, including meetings with past political prisoners, a trip to the African bush, as well as a seminar about the HIV epidemic in South Africa with a leading clinician.

 

Funding for the travel and lodging portion of this trip is our greatest priority, as well as building an endowment that will allow this project to continue and expand. A contribution from you will give us the jumpstart we need while we continue to implement a recently developed series of fundraisers. We believe that this program can make a significant difference for young men who right now find themselves limited by their neighborhoods and income from moving out into the world and expanding their horizons and contributions.

 

Here are some examples of what your
donation can do:
$ 4,000 will fund the entire trip for one student
$ 2,000 will finance both the international and internal flight for one
student.
$ 1,500 will finance all lodging and activities for one student.
$ 500 will finance all activities in Cape Town for one student
$ 100 will finance an overnight stay on Robben Island, the prison where
Nelson Mandela was jailed for 18 years and private tour by an ex
political prisoner.
$ 50 will pay for transportation to and from the townships where the
students will spend four days engaged in social responsibility and
leadership activities with young kids and students from
poverty-stricken areas in South Africa.

 

We believe that our program is consistent with your mission and vision and hope you will support this program. If I can provide additional information to encourage consideration of our request, please feel free to contact me at JBell6871@gmail.com or 347-389-0816.  In addition to this fundraising website, you can donate by writing a check made out to Harry S Truman High School and sending it in care of me at the address below.  I would also be happy to personally meet with you or your committee to present this proposal.

 

Most Sincerely,                                                                                        

 

Jordana Bell   

Global History/African Studies Teacher  

Harry S Truman High School

c/o Jordana Bell

750 Baychester Ave

Bronx, NY 10475                                                Funding Proposal Upon Request

story:
About Me

My name is Deric Mendes. I'm freelance journalist and blogger covering politics, culture and literature. I've written for several Northern Californian publications and have been fortunate to interview a broad scope of people with contrasting ideologies such as Bill Ayers, Karl Rove and Ted Haggard. In 2010 I was a finalist in the Nation's student essay contest. When not studying philosophy and global politics at CSULB, I write a blog called Bold Type, which I publish with Soft Skull Press author, James Reich. Here are a couple observational pieces I did for the North Coast Journal, "Beer Me, Jesus," as well as part 1 and part 2 of my exploration of a shopping mall on the brink of collapse.  

The Project

With your help I plan to travel to Jordan this summer and join my colleague Jordan Hattar (featured in the video above), as well as a documentary film crew from Stanford University, in telling the stories of the Syrian refugees at the Zaatari camp, as well as those in Amman and the outskirts of the city (click here for more information on the Syrian refugee crisis). Hattar has asked me to lend my skills in multimedia, photography,and journalism to take a more in-depth look at the situation than what is being offered by the major media outlets. Hattar hopes that through raising awareness of this situation we can secure semi-permanent housing for families trying to survive the harsh winter ahead. Last year Hattar, in association with Syria Deeply, raised $12,000 for winter accommodations for the camp. This year with help from the Clinton Global Initiative we plan on doing even more for those who have survived immense losses and are now without a home, a country or a clear future. With your help we can present the international community with a clear picture of the situation, hopfully leading to greater efforts towards resolving this crisis.    

For three weeks I will be to reporting daily via Bold Type as well as in any other interested publications. Besides telling the personal stories within the camp I will investigate the socio-economic structure of the camp and talk to officials within the Jordanian government, as well as other aid agencies, to find out what international action/inaction means for the Syrian people and the international commuity at large. We are also in the process of securing an interview with King Abdullah regarding the impact this situation is having on Jordan and what he feels the role of the international community should be now that the crisis is spiraling out of control with over 1 million Syrians fleeing their country.  

How Your Funding Will Be Distributed

  • Airfare, accomodations and food 
  • Translator fees
  • Blankets and toys for the children in the camp
  • transportation and security 

If I fail to raise enough funds your donations will be given to Syran Deeply's Caravan Aid project in the hopes of securing winter housing for the most vulnerable refugee families in the camp. The same will go If I exceed my goal.

What You Get For Donating

Besides giving voice to the Syrian refugees and helping me pursue my journalism profession you can earn extra perks based on your level of funding.

  • $1-10 - All donations are greatly appreciated and will receive a thank you via twitter or Facebook.
  • $50 - We will send you a personal note of thanks and a photo taken while on our trip.
  • $100 - If you own a business or have a website/cause you want to promote, we will add a link of your choice on our homepage as well as the side column seen next to every article. (While Bold Type is a minor publication, due to retweets and links via The Nation, New York Review of Books, and The Rumpus, as well as Facebook shares, your business or cause could be seen by 1000s of unique visitors each time we post)
  • $250 - If you donate $250 or more we will give you a full color ad on our site for three months. 

Other Ways You Can Help

 Even if you can’t contribute, that doesn’t mean you can’t help:

  •  Share this with as many people as you can.
  •  Donate camera and film equipment
  •  Look up Syrian Deeply and get familiar with the issue.
  •  Follow Bold Type and read our posts on the Zaatari camp.
  •  Engage in conversations about this issue and raise awareness. 

THANK YOU!!!

story:
The Philip J. Currie Dinosaur Museum is 10 years in the making and we are now happy to announce that we're breaking ground in April! These are exciting times but we still need your help - a further $7 million is needed to finish the project.

The building is designed, the land is secured, the tendering documents are prepared, and we are currently teaching ten different education programs in area schools. We even have celebrity endorsement. Dan Aykroyd and his family are our International Ambassadors and Criminal Minds’ Matthew Gray Gubler came out last year to help with our big annual fundraiser. Patricia Cornwell, America’s best-selling crime writer’s latest Scarpetta-series book was inspired by her visit to our site last year, calling it The Bonebed.

(Architect's rendering of the museum's Dinosaur Gallery)

Financially, we’ve raised a big chunk of cash: over $20 million of $30 million. We're breaking ground in April and the museum, if all goes well, will host its Grand Opening in June 2014. We still need a bit of help on the way, though. Beyond funding that is presently underway or being confirmed, we still need $7 million more to finish the project. This is where you come in.

But before we get carried away with enthusiasm, let’s back up and explain. There’s no denying dinosaurs are fascinating, the stuff of mythical creatures – only real. We’re lucky – in northern Alberta there are dinosaur fossils everywhere. Palaeontologists have already excavated more than their store rooms can hold.

With such a treasure trove of ancient riches here, we want to build a world-class museum to bring these fossils ‘to life’ as it were. The effort has been underway for 10 years now and for the last two a full-time paid staff of five people has been dedicated to making the museum a reality.

 

(Crew of palaeontologists and visiting celebrities - that's Matthew Gray Gubler in the brown hat - on the Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai bonebed.)

And we have a plan! It’s a good one. The facility will be called the Philip J. Currie Dinosaur Museum, after Canada’s most prolific and popular palaeontologist. It will be 41,000 square feet of world-class technology combined with some of the oldest, most interesting stuff around – fossils dating as far back as 120 million years.

(Architect's drawing of the finished museum building.)

The facility is designed to be a LEED-certified (this means eco-friendly) educational and research centre in the heart of the Peace Country in northwest Alberta, Canada. Its unique shape will be visible from the highway, a silhouette inspired by a dinosaur’s body. Designed by Toronto-based Teeple Architects, the museum will feature extensive gallery spaces, two SMART-technology classrooms, a 64-seat theatre, research and collections areas, a restaurant, gift shop, and tourist services on a three-level design. More details on its exceptionally cool exhibits come at the end of this profile.

(Blueprint graphic of the museum's interior. Courtesy Beauchamp Creative) 

As you can see, a lot has already been done. So what do we need? Dollars, plain and simple. We’re looking for the remaining funds needed to go straight into the capital program. This is the money that will pay for the lumber, nails, engineers and carpenters that will make this museum rise up from the ground.

Why here?

This area has been described as a ‘vertitable gold mine’ by palaeontologists. It all began in 1974 when a young schoolteacher stumbled upon fossilized dinosaur bones. It was a clue that led to the discovery of the world’s densest horned dinosaur bonebed – a jumble of literally thousands of bones, belonging to a new species of dinosaur, Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai. Hundreds of animals died at once, for reasons scientists are still trying to work out. A second horned dinosaur bonebed was discovered in the 1980s.

(Palaeontologists from the Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology excavating the bonebed in 1989.)

Interest has ramped up in the past few years as the area becomes better known internationally as a place of massive palaeontological potential. Scientists from Italy, Trinidad and Spain have come to this area to excavate in the past two years, as have others from the Royal Tyrrell Museum, the University of Alberta and the Royal Ontario Museum.

(Palaeontologist Dr. Phil Bell, project palaeontologist, applies glue to fossilized Hadrosaur skin found on the Red Willow River last year.) 

In the cumulative period of just a few weeks spread out over the past two field seasons, palaeontologists have discovered two skeletons of duck-billed hadrosaurs, replete with impressions of their scaly hide; nearly a dozen footprints from giant tyrannosaurs, hadrosaurs, and ankylosaurs; and a possible new species of small carnivorous dinosaur not unlike the famed Velociraptor from “Jurassic Park”. Even the delicate fossils of plants and tiny insects have been discovered, some of which are new to science. The discoveries will only increase in the coming years. It’s going to be a wonderful thing to be able to bring all the excitement together in one stellar facility.

Education

(Education Manager Laura Beauchamp teaches 'Geology Rocks' to a Grade Three class.)

Education is at the core of this project. We want to bring the science alive for everyone. Our Education Department has created ten delightful, creative and interactive curriculum-connected programs. For Kindergarten to Grade 12, these programs were carefully designed to be portable to school classrooms. They’ll take up residence in the museum once it opens. They’ve proved very popular – over 3,000 students have now participated in a school program.

We also offer entertaining, educational public programs in the summertime, provided by our two summer students. They’re a lot of fun, whether you take a tour to the Pipestone Creek Pachyrhinosaurus bonebed, check out a fossil-handling demonstration or get involved in an audience-participation theatrical performance that changes every year. Over 7,000 people from around the world took part in these over the past two summers. All of these activities will become part of the museum’s educational offerings when it opens its doors.

(Summer student Jewels Goff leads a group on an adventure tour to the dinosaur bonebed.)

With a little help, we'll be opening those doors in 2014. The project is so close to success. It has been underway for 10 years with the last two including the efforts of a five-person project team working full-time to make it happen. With our benevolent army of volunteers, sponsors and helpers, a lot has been accomplished. We have incredible support, all the way to the Grade Four class at Wembley Elementary School, who collected pop cans for an entire year to donate their $1,000 proceeds to the project.

(The Wembley Grade Fours and their generous donation.)

It’s been a lot of work, but it has paid off: it’s a story of great progress. So why not join in? This is going to be a facility for everyone so we figured, why not open it up to everyone to help get it going? Any donation would be hugely appreciated. We will welcome you with open arms to check out ‘your’ museum once the doors open.

(Dan Aykroyd at our 2011 fundraising gala, 'The Aykroyd Family and Friends Dinosaur Ball.)

The Impact

With any donation you’ll be helping create an incredibly cool facility in a place that has more industry than cultural spaces. We want to open up a whole new world in Grande Prairie – a world of scientific intrigue, educational adventure and a glimpse into a past long, long gone.

This museum will have a massive impact on this area. Not only will it be a place for kids (and adults) to get excited and inspired about science, to meet palaeontologists from around the world, and have their minds generally boggled, but it will help diversify the economy and open up the tourism industry here. 

The land is secured – a beautiful 10-acre piece – the museum blueprints are complete, exhibit design is well underway and as mentioned, palaeontologists have discovered a cache of exciting new specimens here during the recent summertime field seasons.

(Site map of the museum's location. Courtesy Beauchamp Creative)

We’re already getting visitors from around the globe coming to check out the bonebed tours we offer to the mass grave site of Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai near Grande Prairie. There is a lot of interest in this, world-wide. We’ve been featured in the Globe and Mail, National Post, TIME Magazine online, Good Morning America and ABC TV’s Born to Explore, to name just a few. The Royal Canadian Mint launched its first glow-in-the-dark coin in May – and guess what it featured? The Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai, the first dinosaur ever discovered in these parts. Its discoverer, one of our present board members, was even featured on The Colbert Report.

(Images of the glow-in-the-dark dino coin. Courtesy the Royal Canadian Mint.)

As you can see, excitement and momentum are abounding with this project. There’s no time to waste. Let’s get it built! We have tons of information on our website, www.curriemuseum.ca as well as our Facebook and Twitter accounts. Or why not give us a call? We’re at (780) 532-2362 in Grande Prairie, Alberta Canada.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re not able to contribute funds you can still help. ‘Like’ us on Facebook, mention us on Twitter (@curriemuseum) and generally make noise on our behalf. We’d really appreciate it.

 

A Little Bit More About Us: The Museum Exhibits

We don’t want to overload you with information but we’re extremely proud of the exhibits designed for this museum. We’ll give you just a brief snapshot of some of our favorites.

Dinosaur Gallery: Fossils everywhere! From towering skeletons overhead to smaller ones underfoot, this Gallery is our showstopper. It features nearly 7,000 sq. feet of an assemblage of intriguing beasts, from Alberta’s newest species never before showcased in a museum to a pantheon of dinosaurs discovered in the Peace Region.

Oil and Gas Wing: Nearly 3,000 sq. feet of interactive discovery – what is the connection between dinosaurs and the industry that powers our world? Kids will love the Discovery Wall, where they pretend to be a drilling rig seeking repositories of oil and natural gas.

Education Centre: Learning concentrates here. Two SMART-technology classrooms and a 64-person theatre will host our hugely popular curriculum-based K-12 programs, lectures by resident and visiting scientists, live performances and special screenings.

Palaeontology Laboratory and Research Centre: A collections area and laboratory where resident and visiting scientists will conduct cutting-edge research. A glass viewing platform gives visitors a bird’s-eye view of all the action.

Special Exhibit Gallery: This gallery will host a wide and ever-changing range of displays and travelling exhibits to be showcased, including art and artifacts.

The Bonebed: Try out your palaeontological skills! The bonebed is a re-creation of a local dig site containing thousands of jumbled bones. Conduct your own prehistoric CSI investigations to crack the case of why hundreds of animals died in one spot.

Time Spiral Staircase: As visitors spiral their way upward they will travel from the prehistoric to the present. Information-graphics representing the different time periods are coupled with actual fossils inserted in the walls of the stairway to illustrate the dazzling diversity of life through time.

Interactive Dig Wall: Visitors put on their palaeo hats at this display. It couldn’t be more hands-on. This re-creation of a dig site allows visitors to use provided tools to slowly excavate replica bones, which they can remove. 

Discovery Tent: This display is a re-creation of a palaeontologist field tent and camp set-up. The tent will be equipped with palaeontological tools and equipment, as well as costumes and other gear for play ‘excavation.’

 

A few Administrative Notes

For those claiming t-shirts or polo shirts as their prizes, we ask that you please include your shirt size in a 'comment.' We are only able to provide Government of Canada tax receipts and to Canadian Citizens only your donation minus the value of the perk you received. We’re sorry, we’d love to give them to everyone but we’ve got to stick to the rules. Our Canadian Charitable Organization number is: 84570 0202 RR00001. For all international donors, the European shipping and handling requests will stand. Thank you all so very much. 

Sponsors

A big thanks to both our present sponsors and all those to come! Thank you!

With such a treasure trove of ancient riches here, we want to build a world-class museum to bring these fossils ‘to life’ as it were. The effort has been underway for 10 years now and for the last two a full-time paid staff of five people has been dedicated to making the museum a reality.
 
(Crew of palaeontologists and visiting celebrities - that's Matthew Gray Gubler in the brown hat - on the Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai bonebed.)
And we have a plan! It’s a good one. The facility will be called the Philip J. Currie Dinosaur Museum, after Canada’s most prolific and popular palaeontologist. It will be 41,000 square feet of world-class technology combined with some of the oldest, most interesting stuff around – fossils dating as far back as 120 million years.

(Architect's drawing of the finished museum building.)
The facility is designed to be a LEED-certified (this means eco-friendly) educational and research centre in the heart of the Peace Country in northwest Alberta, Canada. Its unique shape will be visible from the highway, a silhouette inspired by a dinosaur’s body. Designed by Toronto-based Teeple Architects, the museum will feature extensive gallery spaces, two SMART-technology classrooms, a 64-seat theatre, research and collections areas, a restaurant, gift shop, and tourist services on a three-level design. More details on its exceptionally cool exhibits come at the end of this profile.

(Blueprint graphic of the museum's interior. Courtesy Beauchamp Creative) 
As you can see, a lot has already been done. So what do we need? Dollars, plain and simple. We’re looking for the remaining funds needed to go straight into the capital program. This is the money that will pay for the lumber, nails, engineers and carpenters that will make this museum rise up from the ground.
Why here?
This area has been described as a ‘vertitable gold mine’ by palaeontologists. It all began in 1974 when a young schoolteacher stumbled upon fossilized dinosaur bones. It was a clue that led to the discovery of the world’s densest horned dinosaur bonebed – a jumble of literally thousands of bones, belonging to a new species of dinosaur, Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai. Hundreds of animals died at once, for reasons scientists are still trying to work out. A second horned dinosaur bonebed was discovered in the 1980s.

(Palaeontologists from the Tyrrell Museum of Palaeontology excavating the bonebed in 1989.)
Interest has ramped up in the past few years as the area becomes better known internationally as a place of massive palaeontological potential. Scientists from Italy, Trinidad and Spain have come to this area to excavate in the past two years, as have others from the Royal Tyrrell Museum, the University of Alberta and the Royal Ontario Museum.

(Palaeontologist Dr. Phil Bell, project palaeontologist, applies glue to fossilized Hadrosaur skin found on the Red Willow River last year.) 
In the cumulative period of just a few weeks spread out over the past two field seasons, palaeontologists have discovered two skeletons of duck-billed hadrosaurs, replete with impressions of their scaly hide; nearly a dozen footprints from giant tyrannosaurs, hadrosaurs, and ankylosaurs; and a possible new species of small carnivorous dinosaur not unlike the famed Velociraptor from “Jurassic Park”. Even the delicate fossils of plants and tiny insects have been discovered, some of which are new to science. The discoveries will only increase in the coming years. It’s going to be a wonderful thing to be able to bring all the excitement together in one stellar facility.
Education

(Education Manager Laura Beauchamp teaches 'Geology Rocks' to a Grade Three class.)
Education is at the core of this project. We want to bring the science alive for everyone. Our Education Department has created ten delightful, creative and interactive curriculum-connected programs. For Kindergarten to Grade 12, these programs were carefully designed to be portable to school classrooms. They’ll take up residence in the museum once it opens. They’ve proved very popular – over 3,000 students have now participated in a school program. 
We also offer entertaining, educational public programs in the summertime, provided by our two summer students. They’re a lot of fun, whether you take a tour to the Pipestone Creek Pachyrhinosaurus bonebed, check out a fossil-handling demonstration or get involved in an audience-participation theatrical performance that changes every year. Over 7,000 people from around the world took part in these over the past two summers. All of these activities will become part of the museum’s educational offerings when it opens its doors.

(Summer student Jewels Goff leads a group on an adventure tour to the dinosaur bonebed.)
With a little help, we'll be opening those doors in 2014. The project is so close to success. It has been underway for 10 years with the last two including the efforts of a five-person project team working full-time to make it happen. With our benevolent army of volunteers, sponsors and helpers, a lot has been accomplished. We have incredible support, all the way to the Grade Four class at Wembley Elementary School, who collected pop cans for an entire year to donate their $1,000 proceeds to the project.

(The Wembley Grade Fours and their generous donation.)
It’s been a lot of work, but it has paid off: it’s a story of great progress. So why not join in? This is going to be a facility for everyone so we figured, why not open it up to everyone to help get it going? Any donation would be hugely appreciated. We will welcome you with open arms to check out ‘your’ museum once the doors open.

(Dan Aykroyd at our 2011 fundraising gala, 'The Aykroyd Family and Friends Dinosaur Ball.)
The Impact
With any donation you’ll be helping create an incredibly cool facility in a place that has more industry than cultural spaces. We want to open up a whole new world in Grande Prairie – a world of scientific intrigue, educational adventure and a glimpse into a past long, long gone.
This museum will have a massive impact on this area. Not only will it be a place for kids (and adults) to get excited and inspired about science, to meet palaeontologists from around the world, and have their minds generally boggled, but it will help diversify the economy and open up the tourism industry here. 
The land is secured – a beautiful 10-acre piece – the museum blueprints are complete, exhibit design is well underway and as mentioned, palaeontologists have discovered a cache of exciting new specimens here during the recent summertime field seasons.

(Site map of the museum's location. Courtesy Beauchamp Creative)
We’re already getting visitors from around the globe coming to check out the bonebed tours we offer to the mass grave site of Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai near Grande Prairie. There is a lot of interest in this, world-wide. We’ve been featured in the Globe and Mail, National Post, TIME Magazine online, Good Morning America and ABC TV’s Born to Explore, to name just a few. The Royal Canadian Mint launched its first glow-in-the-dark coin in May – and guess what it featured? The Pachyrhinosaurus lakustai, the first dinosaur ever discovered in these parts. Its discoverer, one of our present board members, was even featured on The Colbert Report.

(Images of the glow-in-the-dark dino coin. Courtesy the Royal Canadian Mint.)
As you can see, excitement and momentum are abounding with this project. There’s no time to waste. Let’s get it built! We have tons of information on our website, www.curriemuseum.ca as well as our Facebook and Twitter accounts. Or why not give us a call? We’re at (780) 532-2362 in Grande Prairie, Alberta Canada.
 
Other Ways You Can Help
If you’re not able to contribute funds you can still help. ‘Like’ us on Facebook, mention us on Twitter (@curriemuseum) and generally make noise on our behalf. We’d really appreciate it.
 
A Little Bit More About Us: The Museum Exhibits
We don’t want to overload you with information but we’re extremely proud of the exhibits designed for this museum. We’ll give you just a brief snapshot of some of our favorites.
Dinosaur Gallery: Fossils everywhere! From towering skeletons overhead to smaller ones underfoot, this Gallery is our showstopper. It features nearly 7,000 sq. feet of an assemblage of intriguing beasts, from Alberta’s newest species never before showcased in a museum to a pantheon of dinosaurs discovered in the Peace Region.
Oil and Gas Wing: Nearly 3,000 sq. feet of interactive discovery – what is the connection between dinosaurs and the industry that powers our world? Kids will love the Discovery Wall, where they pretend to be a drilling rig seeking repositories of oil and natural gas.
Education Centre: Learning concentrates here. Two SMART-technology classrooms and a 64-person theatre will host our hugely popular curriculum-based K-12 programs, lectures by resident and visiting scientists, live performances and special screenings.
Palaeontology Laboratory and Research Centre: A collections area and laboratory where resident and visiting scientists will conduct cutting-edge research. A glass viewing platform gives visitors a bird’s-eye view of all the action.
Special Exhibit Gallery: This gallery will host a wide and ever-changing range of displays and travelling exhibits to be showcased, including art and artifacts.
The Bonebed: Try out your palaeontological skills! The bonebed is a re-creation of a local dig site containing thousands of jumbled bones. Conduct your own prehistoric CSI investigations to crack the case of why hundreds of animals died in one spot.
Time Spiral Staircase: As visitors spiral their way upward they will travel from the prehistoric to the present. Information-graphics representing the different time periods are coupled with actual fossils inserted in the walls of the stairway to illustrate the dazzling diversity of life through time.
Interactive Dig Wall: Visitors put on their palaeo hats at this display. It couldn’t be more hands-on. This re-creation of a dig site allows visitors to use provided tools to slowly excavate replica bones, which they can remove. 
Discovery Tent: This display is a re-creation of a palaeontologist field tent and camp set-up. The tent will be equipped with palaeontological tools and equipment, as well as costumes and other gear for play ‘excavation.’
 
A few Administrative Notes
For those claiming t-shirts or polo shirts as their prizes, we ask that you please include your shirt size in a 'comment.' We are only able to provide Government of Canada tax receipts and to Canadian Citizens only your donation minus the value of the perk you received. We’re sorry, we’d love to give them to everyone but we’ve got to stick to the rules. Our Canadian Charitable Organization number is: 84570 0202 RR00001. For all international donors, the European shipping and handling requests will stand. Thank you all so very much. 
Sponsors
A big thanks to both our present sponsors and all those to come! Thank you!

story:
A Message from Dr Alice Maher and the Emotional Imprint™team

Imagine if, in addition to studying complex languages like Shakespeare, algebra, physics and French, our children could study the equally complex language of emotions. Imagine if they could not only develop greater awareness of self and other, but integrate that variable into their study of other academic subjects.

We believe that “Emotional Literacy” can, and must, be taught. We are developing a curriculum called Emotional Imprint™ that is dedicated to effecting that change in our educational system, one program at a time.

Many young people bully, but the adults around them do too; one need only listen to presidential attack ads to hear it. Many people instinctively treat those perceived as different with distrust, fear and contempt. Such rigid modes of experiencing lead to conflict, and poor social and emotional skills have been negatively correlated with academic success. Existing social and emotional literacy programs have achieved some success; however, they are often squeezed into an already full academic day, and are rarely implemented across grades or cohesively taught.

Emotional Imprint™ takes an innovative pedagogical approach to teaching emotional literacy by integrating it with the existing core curriculum. In an Emotional Imprint™ classroom, young people study the ways in which feelings play a role in learning and decision-making. Through academic work, students develop greater insight into their own and others’ emotions, improve their ability to read and respond to emotional communications of others, and internalize that insight. Our use of thought experiments as a teaching tool encourages students to deepen their understanding of self, other, and text.

This summer we began to put Emotional Imprint™ into action, thanks to an organization called Street Squash, a Harlem-based youth enrichment program that combines academic tutoring with squash instruction and college preparation. Street Squash invited us to design and implement a pilot project for their middle school students.

During the week-long program, we assigned students “future selves.” We turned their classroom into a microcosm of adult society, where each of them used their unique “emotional imprint” to imagine the emotional experience of people from different backgrounds, talk TO rather than AT friends from across imaginary divides, and imagine new ways to effect social change.

Please take a few moments to watch our video, and learn about the program through the eyes and voices of the students.

Pretty amazing, huh? Well, Street Squash thought so too. They’ve invited us back to design a year-long curriculum for their eighth-graders. We're particularly excited about the unique opportunity presented by the Presidential campaign to view current events through a more complex and nuanced lens.

But we need your help. We have the ideas and the track record, but we estimate a total budgetary need of $18,000 in order to continue our important work through the 2012-13 academic year. Your generous contribution will enable us to

  • design the lesson plans and teaching aids for the one week “mini course” and the two 15-week semester courses we are piloting at Street Squash this year
  • train the teachers for all three semesters
  • document and enrich the program with multimedia
  • evaluate the Street Squash pilot projects, so that we can expand and adapt Emotional Imprint™ for use in other academic settings
  • publicize and present Emotional Imprint to educators, allied professionals, parent groups, and the public.

We hope you’ll agree that this is a program worth supporting. This summer the Street Squash students integrated academic and emotional learning, and had a lot of fun.  As you just learned in the video, they’re already thinking about next semester … and beyond.

And we are too. With your help, Emotional Imprint™ can fulfill its mission: to educate, motivate, and enrich students by imagining the emotional experience of others. With your help, they can become engaged and empowered citizens of our country and the world.

Your tax-deductible contribution can be made in one of two ways:
(a) onlline, here at Indiegogo, via the secure PayPal site, or
(b) by check, payable to Changing Our Consciousness, Inc., our non-profit 501(c)3 parent organization. Mail your check to:
     Dr. Alice L Maher
     350 Central Park West, Suite 1G
     New York, NY 10025

Thank you!
Alice, Susan, and the Emotional Imprint Team
http://emotionalimprint.org

story:
Our organization

I started Canadian Friends of Pearl Children(CFPC) after visiting Uganda for the first time in January of 2008. My visit changed my life forever. Since then I have worked tirelessly to raise funds for education, food, healthcare, self-sustainment programs, and women empowerment. The charity has been able to send many children to school and have graduates from university as well. CPFC really needs your help this term. There isn't enough money to send our children back to school. Please help us to help them break the cycle of poverty by getting the education they need.

What We Need

We need $15,000 CAD to send all our primary, secondary and university students back to school. Each student gets tuition, school supplies, dormitory fees, mosquito net and healthcare when needed. If you would like to sponsor a child individually you can visit our website for more information. You would be able to email with your child, receive report cards and have as much or as little contact as you wish.

The Impact

The goal of Canadian Friends of Pearl Children is to send as many children to school as possible and find ways in which communities and villages can become self sustaining.  Help us educate our children so that they may become productive members of society and help their communities to prosper. No donation is too small. Every little bit makes an incredible difference.

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that people can't always help financially, but you can still help us by spreading the word. Tell others about our campaign. Visit our Facebook page for daily updates, "Like"  the page and encourage your friends to "like" it as well. Visit our website at www.pearlchildren.ca and tell your friends. We also encourage you to use indiegogo sharing tools

story:
"The more one does and sees and feels, the more one is able to do, and the more genuine may be one's appreciation of fundamental things like home, and love, and understanding companionship."

Amelia Earhart


Jordan's Story

Hello.  My name is Jordan Savage.  I was born in Victoria, British Columbia, and grew up in Canmore, Alberta.  Ever since I was little I’ve had the desire to become a pilot.  Over the years, I have been influenced by my grandparents and a great uncle to pursue flying as a career.  My first airplane ride was at four years of age when my uncle took me up in a Cessna 172 to fly over the city of Calgary.  I was wowed by the sight of the mountains and the city.  He continued to inspire my love for flying by supplying me with many flight simulator games over the years.  My grandparents on my father’s side of the family used to fly as stunt pilots, and helped me get started by funding my private pilot ground schooling.  Presently, I am working at the Red Deer Regional Airport as a dispatch loading, fueling and marshalling planes for Air Canada, Buffalo Air and even the Ice Pilots.  While I do this, I am also working online to finish my high school classes, and taking a flying lesson here and there, as I can. 

Throughout the years, since I was five years old there has been very challenging circumstances in my life.  When I was five, my step-father was hit by a drunk driver and sustained a severe brain injury.  My mother looked after my stepfather at home, but the accident caused me to miss out on most of my kindergarten year, and I had to take Grade One twice because things were so disruptive at home.  One year I had to spend most of the time staying with my grandfather because things weren’t good at home.  One of the things that got put on hold a lot at my house was my moving ahead smoothly in school, despite the fact that I enjoy learning.  I particularly enjoy math, physics, and anything science-related.  Since the age of fourteen I have also worked after school to help my family with finances.  And now I continue to help my mother and younger sister with living expenses, while my stepfather no longer lives with us.

How can I move ahead with my dream of becoming a pilot?  I can’t seem to work hard enough or fast enough to earn the $10 000 needed to pay for private pilot lessons.  

"The most difficult thing is the decision to act, the rest is merely paper tigers. You can do anything you decide to do. You can act to change and control your life; and the procedure, the process is its own reward."

Amelia Earhart


Jordan's Fundraising Goal:

Jordan is hoping to raise $10 000 to put towards his flying lessons and pilot training. His Aunt Pamela has set up a bank account in trust for Jordan where all donations will be deposited and all money raised will be put towards his pilot training. Any money raised in excess of the goal of $10 000 will be used towards his post-secondary education.

When Jordan sets his mind on a goal he becomes fully engaged with the process and on many occasions has impressed his family. For example, Jordan's step-father Lothar speaks fluent German and several years ago Jordan set his mind to learning German. He was living in Canmore, AB at the time and had a friend who was a German exchange student. People around Jordan soon noticed that he was able to remain focused on his goal and his acquisition of new language skills was apparent. Jordan was invited to visit his friend in Germany as a result of the way that he left such a good impression on his Germany friend and their family.

Jordan is also capable academically at achieving the requirements of pilot training. His marks are above average and he is a quick learner. Jordan does not loose his focus when he sets his mind to a task. He has demonstrated to his family his ability to excel. Jordan clearly loves physics and science and often shares his thoughts regarding scientific concepts, such as, string theory or quantum physics that he is research and reading about.

The Impact of Your Generosity

The impact will significantly empower Jordan to actualize his childhood dream to fly, as well as, provide him with training that can secure a future career for him. Your donations small or large will truly allow him to fly over adversity and achieve his dream.


Thank you for your contributions and support!  Not everyone can contribute but please share Jordan's campaign with your friends on Facebook, Twitter, or Pinterest.

Visit Jordan's blog. He is currently developing it and hopes to be updating it regularly, in order to share some of the interesting adventures he encounters while at work. http://www.jordansdreamtofly.blogspot.com

If you have any questions please contact Jordan's Aunt Pamela at p.savageuvic@gmail.com or if you prefer, make a donation by cheque.

There has been a dedicated bank account set up, in trust for Jordan where all money will be deposited and used to purchase flying lessons for Jordan.

Jordan's campaign is also feature on Backercamp under the title "Projects You Will Love" (http://backercamp.com or @backercamp)

Basic Private Pilot Requirements:
17 Duel
12 Solo
45 Total flight hours
40 Ground school
4 Simulator

Jordan has completed:
5 Duel
2 Simulator
& Former Air Cadet

May God Bless you. Thank you.

"But those that trust in the Lord will find new strength. They will soar high on wings like eagles; they will run and not be weary; they shall walk and not faint."

Isaiah 40:31

"Once you have tasted flight, you will forever walk the earth with your eyes turned skyward, for there you have been, and there you will always long to return."
Leonardo da Vinci


Note: The short link to access this site is https://igg.me/at/Jordansdream/x

Jordan's Dream To Become A Pilot Facebook page
Jordan's new Twitter address is @JordanFlying

story:
Disclaimer: The Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale, based in France, is raising funds to donate to the Isa Viswa Vidyalayam in India. The statements in this campaign are its own and do not necessarily reflect the views of the Isa Viswa Vidyalayam or Isa Viswa Prajnana Trust.


The Isa Viswa Vidyalayam school, in Kerala, India, was founded by His Holiness Swami Isa in 1998.  Here, teachers use a special method of education Swamiji calls “Education for Total Consciousness” (ETC). 

To help educate the expanding enrollment of disadvantaged students in ETC, the Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale is conducting a fundraising campaign for the Isa Viswa Vidyaylayam school.  Any contribution makes a different in helping educate these students, covering the high cost of running the school, and fulfilling Swami’s vision of ETC.  

We are passionate about this form of education because it provides the foundation for children to become truly humane human beings. Please give what you can to sponsor a student and help spread ETC for a better world! 

The Education for Total Consciousness Vision

The Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale holds the belief that every human’s birthright is total knowledge, total awareness, and total happiness that comes from the right kind of education. 

Nowadays even educators do not agree on the purpose of education.  Without a common aim, our knowledge has become fractured and as a society, our direction confused. 

The real purpose of education is to impart wisdom (experienced knowledge) and to perfect the character. These two create total consciousness.

Education for Total Consciousness (ETC) was designed by Swami Isa as a teaching methodology which can be used in any culture and any syllabus. ETC demonstrates the truth that the individual is a microcosm of the universe, and that one's thoughts and actions do have a real effect on the world, just as the world has an effect on one's self.

In ETC, the student links the topic to his or her own self. This is called objective and subjective learning.

Object = anything in the outer world

Subject = myself (my body, my emotions, my intellect, my ego, and Consciousness)

For example, in ETC a story about a baby and a mother becomes a deeper lesson about our own emotions, and a geography lesson on rivers can become a lesson about our circulatory system.

Every single lesson is designed so that the teacher becomes a master of the subject; he or she is compelled to identify completely with the student and topic, and the student likewise with the teacher and topic. 

Students learning in the ETC format will never do harm to others, or exploit nature, for personal gain, because they have direct experience that harm created outside results on harming his or her own self.  Children grow into responsible, broad-minded, compassionate, confident, mindful and loving members of society. 

The Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale is happy to support the Isa Viswa Vidyalayam, as part of a Swami Isa's larger vision to uplift every human being from suffering and ignorance, through Education for Total Consciousness.  We share Swami Isa's ultimate dream to build a Universal University, an International Centre for Total Consciousness, to create an entirely new generation of humane human beings.

Isa Viswa Vidyalayam School

In the Isa Viswa Vidyalayam Swamiji's vision is put into practice. Classes are full of joy and inspiration! There is never a moment of dullness. The students are bright and fresh all day long.

Each morning the students practice meditation and chant vedas before class. They eat together and play together, learn 4 languages (Malayalam, English, Sanskrit and Hindi) in addition to the normal State curriculum, create dances and skits to demonstrate their lessons once a month, visit neighbors to give them trees--the list goes on of amazing things these students do!

And the best part is to see their joy in doing. No matter what it is, these students experience the happiness that comes from things just making sense both outwardly and inwardly. 

"I love my school.  I love my Gurumas [teachers].  I love myself and I love the world," says Kalyani, 3rd Grade. 

What better demonstration of ETC is there?

Why Student Sponsorship?

Many children in the locality of Isa Viswa Vidyalayam in Anayara, Trivandrum, Kerala, come from very humble environments and cannot afford the simple expenses of even a cup of milk or a bus to school. The school pays for the tuition, books, transportation, food and uniforms for these students. But this is a hardship on the day-to-day running, especially in the context of skyrocketing rates for electricity, water and transportation in Kerala State. 

The school has 25 students in need for the 2014-15 school year (June to March). Thus, we would like to raise $15,000 for them.  The money goes to the school to pay for the expenses for the disadvantaged students, as well as the day-to-day operations, including teacher honorariums.  Any excess that we receive will be kept  as a reserve for a residential school we want to help build in the lush tropical jungle of rural Kerala. This school will accommodate more students in a harmonious environment.

We would be extremely grateful if any generous souls wish to donate more for the actual costs of building the new residential school.

In return for your heartwarming support for the students and for this unique educational vision, your name will go on the honor roll of sponsors. Also, the sponsored child will write you a letter and make you a drawing.  You will also get small gifts made by the students in their classes and by other friends and supporters who love this vision.

If we don't reach our entire goal, the amount we do receive will be given to the school for the most needy students. 

The Impact of Your Contribution

Your support for these disadvantaged students will make a profound difference in the lives of 25 families and their communities. The gift of total education is one that radiates to the entire society. 

Meet Swapna (featured on our campaign image). Her father passed away when she was a toddler, and her mother is forced to care for their family on her own.  In this society it is still quite hard for women to make a living, especially if they are not well educated.  We have helped pay for Swapna's education for the past several years, and the previously awkward child is now a confident young woman.

For the past three years, generous individuals and families have been able to sponsor needy students through our charity association. They love the feeling of knowing they make a difference in these students' lives. Sponsors cherish their letters, photos and videos sent by the school, and watch the students grow, year by year.  With these funds the school was able to support the most needy students and also to build a new hall.  It is a heartwarming feeling of satisfaction knowing that we all can make a difference in these students' lives.

Our Other Projects

The Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale is a registered charitable association based in Paris, created in 2009 with the goal to implement positive initiatives in education, culture and environment. The Centre draws great inspiration from the teachings of Swami Isa, especially about total consciousness.

Our objectives are to develop and practice a way of life in balance with nature and environment, to promote harmony between the human being and one's inner and outer universe, and to allow one to uplift one's spiritual consciousness.

Since its implementation, the association Centre Isalayam pour la Conscience Totale has been actively supporting the Isa Viswa Vidyalayam school and its activities through campaigns in France.  This is our first international initiative and we are pleased to reach out to the larger international community on the Indiegogo platform!

Our other activities include:
  • Organization and support for the Global Energy Parliament
  • Organization and support for the National Energy Parliament for France, chaired by Dr. Kiran Vyas
  • Organizing educational exchanges between France and India, to the Isa Universal Centre for Higher Studies, Trivandrum
  • Life for Total Consciousness courses (yoga and meditation technique developed by Swami Isa)
          ->  Free classes for women prisoners
          ->  Child and Adult courses in Paris
          ->  Retreats and Camps in Normandie

Other Ways You Can Help

If you have read this far, it means our message is reaching someone, and that in itself is a wonderful gift!

  • Learn more about the ETC format and attend a Teacher Training Course in India
  • Join a course to train in or teach Life for Total Consciousness
  • Become a Friend or Member of the Global Energy Parliament
  • Send this page to your friends (check out Indiegogo's share tools)
  • Like the Isa Viswa Vidyayalam page on Facebook
  • We love feedback!  Send us an email telling us what you think.

story:
We are students from Boundary Bay Montessori House in Ladner, British

Columbia. Montessori education is a type of school that encourages independent,

experiential, self-paced learning.

     Maria Montessori emphasized the importance of peace education, as she was an

active participant in the League of Nations and writer of the United Nations Rights of

the Child, she believed that peace needs to begin with the child. Montessori said if

we focused on teaching the children how to resolve conflict peacefully, the world

might have a chance of remaining at peace.

     The reason for our Indiegogo campaign is that we are fundraising to get our Grade

seven class to New York City to attend the Montessori Model United Nations conference in April 2014.

     We estimate our costs to get to New York at about $25,000 in total. As students,

we are trying to fundraise 40% of our cost – which is about $10,000, through

activities like chocolate bar sales, a garage sale, bake sales, car washes, and other

activities.

    So far, we have raised around $1000. Our costs include flights, hotel

accommodation, meals and registration fees for the conference. We believe that we

will benefit from this conference by learning about different countries’ perspectives

on global issues, meeting other Montessori students from around the world, as well

as learning problem-solving, negotiation, cross-cultural communication and

leadership skills that will help us in our future life.

    To show our appreciation for your donation for us to attend the conference, we

would like to send you a thank you gift! We have created a hand-painted,

water-colour calendar featuring twelve original paintings of birds, made by all of us

in our art class!

    Or you can receive a link to our trip blog, which we will updating every day during

our time at the MMUN conference in New York.

     Although we would really appreciate any contribution that you can manage, there

are other ways you can help if you cannot donate money.

     Please send this video to your friends and family, and people you know on Facebook

and Twitter, or use the share tools on Indiegogo to get the word out.

     We need lots of help to achieve our goal!


Thank you for supporting the grade seven class at BBMH.
